row.Text:
Taken from [The 7 Essential Meta Questions of Every Beta][1], what information should be found within the FAQ section. Are there certain categories that are explicitly on or off-topic?
[1]: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/the-7-essential-meta-questions-of-every-beta/
What should our FAQ contain?

The economics site may be among the first to require lots of data presentation to enhance discussion of macro-economics. In the same way that the science SE sites have pretty equations, can we have pretty data tables and interactive charts? The work required could be carried across to the statistics site, where I'm sure it would also be useful.
Can we have ways of integrating data?

Some examples of what you're talking about would help a *lot*...
Indeed, I rather suspect this request is premature - until you have a concrete example of a post where the normal formatting / image-embedding falls short, it'll be pretty hard to answer with more than "yes, if they're truly needed.
So for now, **yes you can**... If they're truly needed.

I'm one of the pro-tem moderators of the [Bitcoin SE][1] and there's a bit of crossover between our two sites. I originally thought this would be more of a one-way street with questions clearly economic in nature being misplaced on the Bitcoin site, but within the first few hours of opening I've seen at least three mentions of Bitcoin here and at least one post that might or might not deserve migration, so I'd like to add a conversation here to the one I've [already started][2] in Bitcon's meta.
What criteria do the good folks of the Economics StackExchange think merits the migration of a Bitcoin-related question over to the Bitcoin StackExchange and what criteria do you think we should follow when migrating to you?
[1]: http://bitcoin.stackexchange.com [2]: http://meta.bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/178/economics-migration-criteria
Bitcoin Migration

Obviously one cannot divorce psychology from economics entirely. The behavior of real people can trump any model or theory. As such I assume questions like "How does X behavior influence Y event/market/etc?" are on topic.
However, how far are we willing to go? Are questions like ["Why do voters choose to abstain?"](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/38/what-is-the-swing-voters-curse-in-voting-theory/41#comment-34) on-topic?
How far are we willing to stray into psychology?

Obviously one cannot divorce psychology from economics entirely. The behavior of real people can trump any model or theory. As such I assume questions like "How does X behavior influence Y event/market/etc?" are on topic (for example, http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/43/important-flaws-and-alternatives-to-the-homo-oeconomicus).
However, how far are we willing to go? Are questions like ["Why do voters choose to abstain?"](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/38/what-is-the-swing-voters-curse-in-voting-theory/41#comment-34) on-topic?

The dividing line between behavioral economics (and experimental economics) and psychology is a hazy one indeed. After all, economics is what economists do.
Economics proper does have something to say about the choices people make, indeed that is at the heart of what economists do. So, I don't think that just because one is explaining why one makes one choice or another that the explanation is outside the domain by default.
However, an economic choice can be explained in terms of tradeoffs and optimizing behavior. So, I submit that while the question may be within the domain of economics, some potential answers might not be. In the present case, there are a number of theories that attempt to explain voting choices in economic terms, and these theories are mainstream fodder in most economics graduate programs. Thus, the burden would then fall on those who submit answers to make sure their answers fall within the proper scope.

The border line is probably "marketing psychology" (product placement, shop structuring). This is more a tiny sub-field in business economics. The question is, would important changes in marketing psychology change economic models? Imo clearly NO (there was a time, but there are no big and novel facts to expect anymore). So it doesnt belong here.
But questions about different models of human agents are necessary for exchange and game theory. Afaik alot economic research is done here.
The fact that we still see big economical crisis may be a hint either our human agent or economical models lack detail. So further research has to be done.
A question im unsure is e.g. "Whats origin and purpose of x.99 cent prices" Mixture of economics, history, psychology

The FAQ says:
> The first questions set the tone and topic of a site for a long time. Those early questions say a lot about what your community could become. And questions asked during the private beta will be on the front page when potential experts see your site for the first time. So please make those first questions exemplary ones that are interesting, challenging, and worthy of imitation
This is important. The goal of the economics site is to create a great resource for economists and advanced students of economics. It is not to create a place for Econ 101 students to ask basic questions about the demand curve. If you allow Econ 101 questions during the private beta, then when we open to the public, everybody who knows anything about economics will think that this is a site for beginners and will leave.
We're trying to attract the worlds' experts in economics, here, to make a fantastically valuable resource for the Internet beyond what the big Q&A sites have.
If you see questions that you think any first year student should know the answer to, or questions which sound like 18 year-olds might ask a professor, *close them as off-topic*.
Remember, exemplary questions

I don't understand why the two can't coexist.
If both groups get the answer they seek is that a tragedy?
I'd rather differentiate by tags than to go around deleting all questions that don't use Bellman equations

Using [my question](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/what-determines-the-shape-of-the-demand-curve) as your example breaks down a bit because, again, it specifically is not covered in my ECON 101 course. We talked a fair bit about factors affecting demand — what could push the curve outwards, selecting a price point given a curve, etc. — but nothing about what determines the shape of the curve. And that's why I asked the question.
My introductory paragraph was intended to indicate that the very basics, like [segmentation](http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/CamelsandRubberDuckies.html), weren't the subject of the question. You yourself said:
>You can't really find out what the demand curve is.
>...
>The more you learn about pricing, the less you seem to know.
So, understanding the shape of the curve for the purposes of pricing seems like a complex endeavor (at least to you and me, anyways :P). I don't consider the current answers satisfactory in that regard; I'd like to see more information like [Ryan's comment on MikeRand's answer](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/what-determines-the-shape-of-the-demand-curve#comment-14). It mentions Engel curves and Veblen/Giffen goods, things that are **definitely** not mentioned in my microeconomics class. [My professor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Smith_(economics)) is no slouch, either. I would be extremely surprised if he skipped anything basic or fundamental in his course.
Being on the receiving end of Joel Spolsky's first downvote on a new site is kind of exciting, I suppose, but I'd prefer to have my question open and answerable :P. I totally agree with avoiding basic questions, but I don't think this is what you're making it out to be. If it doesn't meet the standard, that's fine, but obviously the standard would be higher than merely "beyond ECON 101" in that case.
If that ***is*** the case, I'll have to ask the SE team to cancel my commitment to this site, because this is not what I foresaw. The definition questions are honestly pretty terrible, but the immense gulf between them and your ideal makes the definition phase completely worthless. I've been through several beta launches but nothing has struck me as quite this pointless. Check out the top 4 definition questions:
- [What was Milton Friedman's position on why the Great Depression happened?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/1845#1845)
If not general reference, this is certainly not an expert question. The answer would just be copy-pasted facts; there's no room for applying expertise in relating someone else's opinion. Any layman could read someone's opinion and summarize it.
- [What is a prime example of "the tragedy of the commons"?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/2131#2131)
List question, subjective, basic — you name it, this question's got it. Interesting, maybe; expert, no. The Wikipedia article even [has good examples](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons#Modern_commons).
- [What is a sunk cost?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/7726#7726)
This would get so many "Google it" comments you'd have to lock the post.
- [What is the "permanent income hypothesis"?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/2126#2126)
Slightly more interesting than the last, but the first Google hit is Wikipedia and [the article](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_income_hypothesis)'s pretty decent.
I honestly don't understand the rationale behind signing up a bunch of people who ask and are interested in these sort of questions and then expecting them to churn out super-expert questions. It doesn't help that [the Research Economics proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/24653/research-economics) is still open. If all the Master's and Doctorate students are here, what's the point of that?
Finally: Whatever the guideline is, it needs to be made clearer. For example, here's some of the questions you left open:
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/3/what-are-some-of-the-options-and-consequences-available-to-greece
This was covered in my first year macroeconomics class (ECON 102).
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/13/how-does-the-perfect-competition-model-break-down-when-one-of-the-six-assumptions
This was covered in my first year microeconomics class (ECON 101).
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/43/important-flaws-and-alternatives-to-the-homo-oeconomicus
Addressed in both of the above courses.
In summary: I'm really confused, and I can only assume others are too. Including you guys at SE, or otherwise this would be sorted out. I mean that constructively.

@Matthew Read
Why voters choose to abstain is NOT a psychological question. There are rational reasons for abstaining from voting which mainstream economists have been writing about for many years. Let me give you a few links to papers in the best economics journals; hope they will disabuse you of the misconceptions you seem to harbor.
http://www.jstor.org/pss/2118204
http://www.nber.org/papers/w14799
With all due respect, why would close a discussion you have no idea about?

Since there seems to be a lot of confusion about what is a legitimate question on this forum and what is not, let me make a suggestion about how to make up our minds.
If there is a question, for example on the Revelation Principle, or Voting Theory, or Structural Models, and you don't know what that is, please do a quick search on google scholar and see if economics journals are publishing papers related to the question. If such papers are being published, accept that there are parts of economics you don't know about, and let the question be, please. Is this an acceptable solution?
Of course, I don't mean to imply if no papers are being written on the topic it is not a valid question. If you don't find any current research on the topic you are free to use your judgement.
Is having a quick look at current research trends in economics a fair way to decide whether something is off-topic?

The thing I think is most fascinating about the Econ SE site is the timing… right at this moment the US is divided into 2 large factions with irreconcilable economic policy beliefs. (I.e. the borrow-and-spend stimulus faction and the trickle-down supply-side faction.) These two different dogmas are built up on nearly a century of divergent economic opinion that has swung back and forth several times.
I suspect the majority of American's don't have a foggy clue what either of these ideologies actually entails, and I hope that Econ SE can be a forum for explaining specific economic beliefs more clearly. (E.g. explaining a specific term used by Keynes using modern language, not 1930's econ-babble.)
At the same time, I can already see arguments brewing around questions that are not specific, such as this one: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/12/what-are-the-effects-of-turning-a-backed-currency-into-a-fiat-currency/53#53
This question really exposes a wide chasm of beliefs in modern economics, one that is not anywhere close to being resolved. How do we navigate tricky questions like this? How do we prevent one ideology from being consistently voted up and another one consistently voted down? Should we close an issue if it is phrased in such a way that it will provoke arguments?
Where do we draw the line on ideological questions?

These sorts of arguments don't often occur among economists, at least not until the wine starts flowing. When questions have political implications, we tend to avoid making any normative conclusions--we don't say what is better/worse, but rather limit ourselves to if/then statements. That is, given a set of assumptions and certain parameters, one can show that a certain outcome will result. This is quite different from the answers people generally expect, and is a great opportunity to demonstrate how economic thinking really works.
In my opinion, answers to such questions should rely on well-known models or empirical evidence (like the Wikipedia prohibition on "original research"), and the answer should define the limits of the conclusions. This will be a very difficult task as it is hard to communicate that models are abstractions, that our insights usually come from these abstractions, and that they can lend certain insights but usually cannot give authoritative answers. So, few questions would be inappropriate, but many possible answers would be.

As long as questions and answers make it clear that the poster has set out their assumptions, and the limits of their conclusions, it should be fine.
Even bunfights between Keynesians, Monetarists and Austrians can settle down into agreements about "well, if you take those assumptions, then yes, that conclusion is valid; but if instead you take these asssumptions, then this conclusion is valid"
I do suspect that when the site goes public beta, we might get an influx of goldbugs and the like. Hopefully a handful of definitive questions on money supply, velocity of money, and the like, will mean that almost all incoming questions on the subject can be rapidly closed either as argumentative or as duplicates.

Is "Why do voters choose to abstain?" on-topic?
Almost.
With a bit of editing, yes. If phrased in some other ways, no.
I'd hope we'd edit the question to say something like: "what's the behavioural economics of voter abstention?", to encourage answerers to stay on-topic; and that we'd flag up answers that weren't grounded in economics.

I imagine that you write this based on your experience with this question: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/38/what-is-the-swing-voters-curse-in-voting-theory
I think that the problem is not about the readers of your question, but about the question itself. If you add more context to your question, including what you already saw in the literature, then it will become visible that you are asking an actual "economics" question. You are the one that ask the question so you should provide the context, it is not to the readers to find for additional information.
By the way, I think that your "I'm doing a phd in economics and I think I know what's on topic and what's off" is not a fact. This is the community that decides what's on topic or not, not you (or me or anyone else in particular). Moreover, your are probably not the only one with a degree/academic record in economics here, so *argumentum ad baculum* is not of any interest on stack exchange, don't you think ?
I remember reading somewhere that, when it comes to such questions, "Economics cannot answer normative questions" - so the test could be as to how normative a particular question is?

Yes, I agree with your assertion that:
> If there is a question, for example on the Revelation Principle, or > Voting Theory, or Structural Models, and you don't know what that is, > please do a quick search on google scholar and see if economics > journals are publishing papers related to the question. If such papers > are being published, accept that there are parts of economics you > don't know about, and let the question be, please.
However, if the community didn't pick up, from the question itself, that it belongs on here, then there's scope to improve the question by including more context, to establish its economic credentials without a reader having to go do Google Scholar searches. So I agree with @Sylvain Peyronnet too:
> If you add more context to your question, including what you > already saw in the literature, then it will become visible that you > are asking an actual "economics" question. You are the one that ask > the question so you should provide the context
Why not edit that question on Swing Voter's Curse a bit more, give some more context including the (behavioural) economics therein, and give people a chance to revisit their "close" votes and maybe vote to reopen?

The FAQ says:
> The first questions set the tone and topic of a site for a long time. Those early questions say a lot about what your community could become. And questions asked during the private beta will be on the front page when potential experts see your site for the first time. So please make those first questions exemplary ones that are interesting, challenging, and worthy of imitation
This is important. The goal of the economics site is to create a great resource for economists and advanced students of economics. It is not to create a place for Econ 101 students to ask basic questions about the demand curve. If you allow Econ 101 questions during the private beta, then when we open to the public, everybody who knows anything about economics will think that this is a site for beginners and will leave.
We're trying to attract the worlds' experts in economics, here, to make a fantastically valuable resource for the Internet beyond what the big Q&A sites have.
If you see questions that you think any first year student should know the answer to, or questions which sound like 18 year-olds might ask a professor, *close them as off-topic*.
**EDIT**
I've watched quite a few sites get launched now where I know some experts in the field. I've spoken to quants about quant, linguists about linguistics, statisticians about stats, and Japanese about japanese. I show them the site, proud as can be, and what they tend to say is, "this site looks stupid. It's a bunch of beginners." Ouch.
Nothing hurts a site more than making the experts think that the site is stupid or intended for beginners. I can't think how many people who would have made those sites great but did not participate because well-meaning private-beta participants filled the site up with a bunch of really basic questions.
Don't let this happen here. If you aren't an economist, that's fine. Wait until after the private beta.

The thing I think is most fascinating about the Econ SE site is the timing… right at this moment the US is divided into 2 large factions with irreconcilable economic policy beliefs. (I.e. the borrow-and-spend stimulus faction and the trickle-down supply-side faction.) These two different dogmas are built up on nearly a century of divergent economic opinion that has swung back and forth several times.
I suspect the majority of American's don't have a foggy clue what either of these ideologies actually entails, and I hope that Econ SE can be a forum for explaining specific economic beliefs more clearly. (E.g. explaining a specific term used by Keynes using modern language, not 1930's econ-babble.)
At the same time, I can already see arguments brewing around questions that are not specific, such as this one: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/12/what-are-the-effects-of-turning-a-backed-currency-into-a-fiat-currency/53#53
This question really exposes a wide chasm of beliefs in modern economics, one that is not anywhere close to being resolved. How do we navigate tricky questions like this? How do we prevent one ideology from being consistently voted up and another one consistently voted down? Should we close an issue if it is phrased in such a way that it will provoke arguments?
Edit -- Examples of potentially problematic questions:
http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/74/why-did-treasuries-yield-plunge-after-usa-was-downgraded
This isn't really a research economics question, and I could see several competing theories being put forth in response. I'm used to stack overflow, where it's fairly easy to copy/paste into a compiler and determine whether something is basically correct or not.
http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/72/what-is-the-economics-behind-across-the-board-failure-of-communist-leftist-gove
Uses "leftist" as a pejorative, and asks for explanations of phenomena that have dozens of hundreds of interlocking factors.
http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/3/what-are-some-of-the-options-and-consequences-available-to-greece
This is a split across two different theories. One theory argues that austerity, deleveraging, and deflation are the best course of action. Another theory suggests this can be solved with monetary policy. What is an impartial answer to this question going to look like? (Actually the current most popular answer is a good, impartial answer to a potentially political question. But other answers and comments seem to be unsupported and make normative claims about certain policy outcomes.)
http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/19/how-do-friedman-and-bernankes-explanations-about-the-causes-of-the-great-depress
This question actually resulted in a very nice answer, but I think we can all see how this same question (when opened up to the public) could result in some argument.
*In short*, I don't agree with the dismissal of my question. "That won't happen" isn't a good answer. We should have guidelines to objectively identify when a question or answer goes out of bounds and have tips for writers to fix those things so that they become useful.
What’s the “elevator pitch” for our site?

I don't know why Joel closed it as off-topic, frankly. As I noted I thought it was too basic. You pretty much just asked for the definition. In your comment you asked a more expansive question, but SE is not a back-and-forth discussion forum. Your question needs to be well-formed and complete initially in order to get the response you would expect to a well-formed and complete question; comments are for minor clarifications. If your goal is to get information beyond the definition, you need to specify that in the question.
Crowd-sourcing great questions and great answers about economics

http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/87/what-is-the-optimal-policy-response-for-a-country-experiencing-a-liquidity-trap
A normative question. CarrKnight has a really nice answer that begins with "It really depends on what your model says it's the cause of the liquidity trap." I think this is exactly how we should aim to answer normative questions. (Thanks JasonB for pointing this out.)

If it's specific to bitcoin, then get it off this site; either deleted or migrated to bitcoin.
If it's not specific to BitCoin, then remove all the Bitcoin references, and leave it as a general question about stateless currencies with fixed circulation.

I understand the desire to draw experts to the community, but the restriction of "graduate level" or higher economics questions seems to me like it unnecessarily fragments the community and perhaps creates an image of elitism. I truly do understand the desire to not relive Econ101 but I do foresee a great deal of users coming to this site with questions that the current standards will deem "too simple" to answer. A large number of our users will likely be college students, struggling to understand the basics and while that seems aweful now, weren't we all there once?
Should we perhaps widen our scope a bit? I'm not aware of any other StackExchange that has such a policy - for example StackOverflow does not, to my knowledge, dismiss a programming question for being "too basic." It's our choice as a community, which is why I'm asking it here: how would you, the people, feel about potentially widening the scope to allow perhaps all collegiate level questions?
"Graduate Level" Questions
I believe this is a good idea. I cannot see that it would be that offensive to see Econ101 questions asked here, even for the most hard-core economists.

[Joel's question][1] on this meta site sets out the reasoning very clearly, and I find it very persuasive. Some choice excerpts, with my emphasis:
> The goal of the economics site is to create a great resource for > economists and advanced students of economics. It is not to create a > place for Econ 101 students to ask basic questions about the demand > curve. **If you allow Econ 101 questions during the private beta, then > when we open to the public, everybody who knows anything about > economics will think that this is a site for beginners and will leave.** ... > Nothing hurts a site more than making the experts think that the site > is stupid or intended for beginners. I can't think how many people who > would have made those sites great but did not participate because > well-meaning private-beta participants filled the site up with a bunch > of really basic questions
Remember, the author of those words has launched many successful, and some unsuccesful Q&A sites very like this one. Heed the voice of experience.
And remember that the call for exemplary question applies to the early stages of the beta. If you have more basic questions, why not just put them on ice until we've built up a decent number of expert questions and expert answers?
[1]: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/remember-exemplary-questions

Joel's intent, I believe, is to discourage us from seeding the site with easy question. By easy, I mean things like "What is elasticity?" While at some point we may make the decision to allow these questions, initially we should stay away from them as much as possible.
The questions asked in first few days will determine what kind of community we will be entering public beta with. If most experts on the topic feel it is way too basic, or uninteresting, we will be entering public beta with a community that is less qualified than otherwise - and with content less interesting with the experts we want to attract. Easy questions can be asked later, but not during private beta. At this point, in the site's infancy, they are detrimental to the site's growth.

To be honest, I fully intended to seed a few good graduate-level questions but, after several attempts, have had difficulty coming up with any. Everything I've come up with so far has fallen into four categories:
1. Questions I can answer in a literature search (or by reference to a book on my shelf or even Wikipedia) 2. Questions that would require original research to answer (almost by definition, if the question isn't answered by (1), it would require new research). 3. Questions about the apex literature in a field of economics. I usually find a course syllabus or ask a colleague to answer these sorts of questions. 4. Questions that seem like homework, and could be sorted if I just took the time to do so (for example, I'd need to do a bit of reading to get a grip on the subject, but want someone else to spoon-feed it to me). At least on SO, such questions aren't usually appreciated, so I assume the same goes here.
Perhaps I'm not very creative (and I apologize if I'm just too dense), but I'm starting to wonder just what would make a good graduate-level question (and whether the powers that be on this site might need to re-consider the mandate). Are any of the questions asked so far considered "graduate level" without fitting into (1)-(4) above?
I say the above with deep respect for the SE process--I'm assuming that **I** don't get something here. But, others are probably in the same boat, so some clarification might help.

It mentions Engel curves and Veblen/Giffen goods, things that are **definitely** not mentioned in my microeconomics class. [My professor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Smith_(economics)) is no slouch, either. I would be extremely surprised if he skipped anything basic or fundamental in his course.
Being on the receiving end of Joel Spolsky's first downvote on a new site is kind of exciting, I suppose, but I'd prefer to have my question open and answerable :P (edit: the community has re-opened it, thanks to several of you for the good answers and explication). I totally agree with avoiding basic questions, but I don't think this is what you're making it out to be. If it doesn't meet the standard, that's fine, but obviously the standard would be higher than merely "beyond ECON 101" in that case.
If that ***is*** the case, I'll have to ask the SE team to cancel my commitment to this site, because this is not what I foresaw. The definition questions are honestly pretty terrible, but the immense gulf between them and your ideal makes the definition phase completely worthless. I've been through several beta launches but nothing has struck me as quite this pointless. Check out the top 4 definition questions:
- [What was Milton Friedman's position on why the Great Depression happened?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/1845#1845)
If not general reference, this is certainly not an expert question. The answer would just be copy-pasted facts; there's no room for applying expertise in relating someone else's opinion. Any layman could read someone's opinion and summarize it.
- [What is a prime example of "the tragedy of the commons"?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/2131#2131)
List question, subjective, basic — you name it, this question's got it. Interesting, maybe; expert, no. The Wikipedia article even [has good examples](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons#Modern_commons).
- [What is a sunk cost?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/7726#7726)
This would get so many "Google it" comments you'd have to lock the post.
- [What is the "permanent income hypothesis"?](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics/2126#2126)
Slightly more interesting than the last, but the first Google hit is Wikipedia and [the article](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_income_hypothesis)'s pretty decent.
I honestly don't understand the rationale behind signing up a bunch of people who ask and are interested in these sort of questions and then expecting them to churn out super-expert questions. It doesn't help that [the Research Economics proposal](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/24653/research-economics) is still open. If all the Master's and Doctorate students are here, what's the point of that?
Finally: Whatever the guideline is, it needs to be made clearer. For example, here's some of the questions you left open:
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/3/what-are-some-of-the-options-and-consequences-available-to-greece
This was covered in my first year macroeconomics class (ECON 102).
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/13/how-does-the-perfect-competition-model-break-down-when-one-of-the-six-assumptions
This was covered in my first year microeconomics class (ECON 101).
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/43/important-flaws-and-alternatives-to-the-homo-oeconomicus
Addressed in both of the above courses.
>Nothing hurts a site more than making the experts think that the site is stupid or intended for beginners. I can't think how many people who would have made those sites great but did not participate because well-meaning private-beta participants filled the site up with a bunch of really basic questions.
>Don't let this happen here. If you aren't an economist, that's fine. Wait until after the private beta.
Does that really make sense? The experts will enjoy crap questions as long at they're not posted during the private beta? That's bizarre. There might be some sort of lock-in effect — experts who get active early may be more reluctant to leave later — but there are at least two counters to that:
- The experts will feel suckered. They can come here and read what you're saying, you know. Attempting to trick them into believing this site is for experts only to allow the beginners to inundate the site later can't go over well.
- The initial experts aren't enough. There are two few people on the site right now for it to be viable long-term, so we have to grow. To grow, we need to be attractive to new users. If we want those new users to be experts, then we will **always** need to avoid the "stupid beginner questions". If not, then the site's not a site for experts anyways so why do we care about them at all?
And aren't the biggest sites in the network the ones that don't cater only to PhDs? Didn't SO allow terrible questions once and still manage to get huge and attract the likes of Eric Lippert? (I'm not advocating bad questions, just pointing out that the logic isn't 100% sound here.)
In summary: I'm really confused, and I can only assume others are too. Including you guys at SE, or otherwise this would be sorted out. I mean that constructively.

Enable MathJax for formulas?

I think there needs to be initial "seeding" that keeps the level of discussion at a professional/graudate level but - especially if the topics start returning high in search results - we are going to get people with either particular economic opinions to push, or non-economists worried or perplexed by events. The latter are likely to aks, and need, answers to Eco101 questions.
Another question to resolve is whether this site is only for working economists, or whether interested bystanders are welcome? Economics is one of the few academic subjects where layman feel quite comfortable getting involved so this sort of scoping is quite important.

It's probably way too early to start thinking about making our tags a bit saner.
But one thing did occur to me. I'm guessing that a very high proportion of questions might merit either a "macroeconomics" or a "microeconomics" tag. But in that case, doesn't that make them so general as to be useless?
on tags (possibly prematurely) - macroeconomics / microeconomics
Yes. They're barely above an `economics` tag.

**Strapline**: Maximised utility
**Elevator pitch**: The Economics Stackexchange - a website where lay people and experts ask awesome questions about economics, and get awesome answers. Peer-voting helps the best answers rise to the top.

A place to discuss general, but also advanced questions about Economics and Economics research.
I'm a little biased, but I'd really like to make sure there is something in the tag-line or elevator pitch that would make sure to attract questions that are of graduate-level or higher caliber.

We should also avoid questions that the majority of working economists would deem as "unanswerable" or too likely to appear as quack questions like in the popular press.
For instance, questions of the type "How will the economy grow in Q4 of 2011", "Should I buy bonds or stocks", or similar questions should be discouraged. They are really better suited for a forum on finance or investing and definitely do not represent anything related to the study of economics.
This stackoverflow should **NOT** be a forum for lay people to have baseless arguments about generally unknowable or highly opinionated questions.

This is absolutely a good idea. If you want there to be good discussions on graduate or research-level economics, not having \LaTeX enabled would discourage a lot of people.
This should be done immediately so that initial questions can be seeded with \LaTeX.
I will probably walk from the site (I'm an econ grad student at MIT) if it doesn't have this capability and I imagine many other grad students would too.

To date, we've received a couple of questions on statistical methods:
- http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/192/if-you-have-a-really-big-n-is-using-a-regular-vs-an-m-n-bootstrap-ever-a-good - http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/202/does-it-make-sense-to-cluster-when-you-use-a-regression-discontinuity
ISTM that these are best placed on stats.SE, and that these two questions in particular should be migrated there.
I think that there is a subtle distiction between between technical questions about economics, and technical questions by economists: the latter might include questions about stats (stats.SE), or programming a particular algorithm (stackoverflow). The advantages of taking a question such as this to stats.SE, is that there are a lot more people there who will be well-placed to give a great answer (which means that everyone benefits); and that non-economist statisticians will be interested in the same question and the same answer (reaching a wider audience).
where stats questions belong

As a regular visitor of stats.SE (and coincidentally the top user in econometrics tag [there][1] :)), I would say that the first question belongs to stats.SE, while the second one belongs here.
The remark about wider audience is spot on. For the first question a lot of statisticians can have an opinion, for the second one too much econometrics jargon is used for statisticians to be able to say what is what.
Note though that this site is only starting up, so when there is a benefit of the doubt, the question should remain here. Furthermore migrating mechanisms are not there yet, if I recall correctly, they work only for sites which graduate from beta.
[1]: http://stats.stackexchange.com/tags/econometrics/topusers
where do economics stats questions belong?

I agree with most of what the other posters said regarding eliminating questions that are excessively normative, vague, or unanswerable by economists.
One way these questions *could* be phrased, though this may be less exciting to the question answerer is to have the question re-written so that it asks for specific academic studies on the question.
For example, a question such as, "Does our safety net cause people to be lazy and not work?" is kind of vague and unanswerable as it stands. However, if the question was phrased as, "What have economists said about of generous welfare benefits on unemployment durations?" that would be answerable.
There are some problems with this: 1) Community members may not have the desire to "translate" flaming questions into objective economic ones 2) Depending on who the SE attracts, these questions could get flamy and take over 3) The original question-asker may not be happy with such a boring answer and may not have the desire to read academic economists' take on the question... they might be better off reading WSJ, NYTimes, or the Economist (depending on their political persuasion).
In the case of (3), this "translation" isn't really helpful and the question-asker may be better off visiting forums for political discussion.

I've been a regular contributor to the Personal Finance Stackexchange site for the past year or so and straight from private beta as well. My experience there, with similar queries ("Do macro-economics questions belong in Personal Finance?") is that people are going to ask them. There is overlap and that a strictly definitional approach ("This is a stats question, this is a programming question.") doesn't recognise that there will always be messy overlap.
An economist is not necessarily a statistion and may not know what the appropriate method should be. They can describe their problem, using familiar economic definitions, and get an answer from an economist with stats knowledge. Ditto algorithms, programs, and so on.
An economist going to Stackoverflow and describing their problem in economic terms is unlikely to be understood.
I'd recommend that we permit, without promoting, such grey areas and recognise that economists need to grapple with stats and software on their own terms.
On Personal Finance it was agreed that many people do want to understand why certain economic decisions are made and how those influence their personal finance or taxes. It rounded out the site nicely.

Skeptics SE requires references in its answers and notable claims in its questions. I Think that this policy may make sense here though I would modify it slightly.
- Any claim of statistical trends, or actual economic conditions in a question should be required to be referenced.
- If the question is is the trend actually happening then the claim should be able to be referenced by some notable news source.
- Since these should be graduate level questions the Questioners should at least be able to show some relevant knowledge of the question and that they have at least attempted research by referencing documents of the topic where they are seeking clarification that does not fall into the previous categories. This would include questions of how does X fit with Y or What do economists say about Z.
- Since these are graduate level questions all answers should be able to be referenced.
These policies should help to mostly eliminate less useful and political questions about the economy. Or at least put them into an arena where they can be addressed with out the left vs right agenda pushing with out real data or research to back it up. The good questions I have seen seem to already be following this.
Does this not seem like a good policy?
A call for references

I agree in general, but there is no need to take things to extremes.
IMHO, the fact that this site is aimed at graduate and professional economists means that the citation requirements might be more relaxed. Among this group, there are certain well-known facts.
Using [the question](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/246/what-have-economists-written-about-the-recent-rise-in-income-inequality) that, I assume, inspired your post above (not my question BTW):
- There would be no argument among economists that income inequality has risen in the U.S. over recent decades. This is something we know, and we would no more search for a citation on this fact than we would find a citation that "U.S. GDP is higher than Canadian GDP." - **But**, we would be precise about what we mean by income inequality (e.g. "... as measured by the Gini coefficient on household income") and the region we are talking about (a certain country, state/province, global,...).
In my opinion, the question fails to define what it means by income inequality, but no citation is needed to say that income inequality is rising.
In the comments to that question, I said that, as measured by the Gini coefficient, income inequality is rising in the United States... a very specific (and falsifiable) answer. You asked for proof, and I think that reveals an extreme view of the sorts of evidence that are required. That answer was a fact, and is very easily looked up.
**In my opinion, we can not make a blanket requirement for proof of every trend.** One needs to use discretion and professional experience to decide when citation is necessary.
I'm not making this a personal argument, but another case-in-point is in your answer to another question ([Is physical gold inflation-proof?](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/187/is-physical-gold-inflation-proof/247#247)), you state "If you hold gold over time it will probably resist inflation. " Why you think that sort of statement doesn't require citation, but that well-known trends do need to be cited is rather beyond my comprehension. Does the addition of the word "probably" excuse the need for citation? But, I agree that your statement does not require citation, exactly because it is fairly well-known that gold is an inflation hedge.
In short, if you are right that this site is "by professionals for professionals", then I'd argue that we should rely on personal judgement to decide what needs to be cited and avoid any sort of rule that everything must be cited. StackExchange questions and answers are not formal publications.

I think you've made some good points. Over on physics.SE, English.SE or Math.SE, references are seen as contributing to good questions and good answers, but are not compulsory. On skeptics.SE, the bar is set higher, with an expectation that answers **are** referenced.
"all answers should be able to be referenced." is ambiguous. And maybe there's value in that ambiguity. It is not the same as saying that "all answers should be referenced." - I don't think that would be a helpful criterion for the site as a whole; (I can see that we might aspire to that as a criterion during the private beta).
I think that it's important to bear in mind that this is a public website. It is not a private website for professionals. The audience is, and will be, academic economists, professional economists, and the general public.
If a question isn't of high enough standard, then in general, downvote it. [And while we're in the private beta, vote to close it as off-topic][1].
[1]: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/q/9/104

- Since these should be graduate level questions the Questioners should at least be able (and required) to show some relevant knowledge of the question and that they have at least attempted research by referencing documents of the topic where they are seeking clarification that does not fall into the previous categories. Taken from [The 7 Essential Meta Questions of Every Beta][1], what information should be found within the FAQ section. Are there certain categories that are explicitly on or off-topic?
Note that the FAQ section is for frequently asked questions *about* the site and not merely questions that get asked *on* the Q&A site a lot. Determining the FAQ properly helps to clarify the scope and intent of the site.

I believe that it should state that any economics topic is on-topic including:
- Game theory - History of economics theory - History of the world economy - Study of incentives (this needs rewording) - Parts of consumer behavior that are strongly related to economics - Theories and models from economics applied to other areas of study - Data sources relevant for economists - Sources of any kind (including magazines) that are relevant or often used by hard-core economists
The reason why I want to include many border line topics, is that I believe that economists will not be offended by seeing these topics here. Also, I believe that the current pool of economists that are active on stack exchanges is limited, so economists that are interested in non-mainstream economics, should be welcomed. I believe that the initial success of stackoverflow was due to its scope being relatively broad. Later on it has been narrowed down slightly with off-shoots like superuser.com, serverfault.com and the Database Administrator stackexchange. The same could be done for this site, for example when/if the [game theory stack exchange][1] reaches enough committers.
What do you think?

I thought I might chime in. For what it's worth, I have quite a lot of economics background - a graduate-level economics background, in particular. I'm hoping to make a career out of economic research at the frontier of knowledge and methodology, if I can help it. I'm just about to enter the "research" phase of my PhD, and would absolutely love to have a site where I can ask (and answer!) questions that are either research-related or "theory-backed policy or analysis"-related (heck empirical questions would be fine too). That'd be great.
Something that I (and friends of mine) been trying to figure out since the beta launch is "what level" this SE site is aiming for. Saying that a site should have questions in the range
"Econ 101" < ideal question <= graduate-level questions
is a pretty big range.
I mention this, of course, because I just witnessed what appears to be a pretty legitimate research-level-type [question attacked][1] for not including what the person was asking about -- references to literature about that topic.
I definitely consider that question to be a "literature review" type question, which I welcome and have no problem with. Here's why: part of being an expert in something means knowing that particular literature well. At the same time, you explicitly *don't* know the literature of other sub-fields well. That's fine, that's how being a researcher is designed. Expert in a narrow area and all. There is no shame in asking an expert in another sub-field what the literature in that field is. Thus the response to the question, that it should essentially *include* literature in its phrasing, strikes me as strange -- for a research-related site.
The response to the question makes a lot of sense, of course, if the site is supposed to be a place for people to debate current topics. "Back up your terminology!" and all. I was under the impression that that's not the point of this site, though.
It's terminology for heavens sake. He's asking for references to that particular area. Terms like "income inequality" are *common* in titles and abstracts to journal articles.
The other thing that prompted my question is that, as I was reading the above debate, another friend of mine -- doing economic research at the PhD level and following the site -- sent me a message: "looks like no ones answered [your question][2] yet. You think anyone will?"
Not that my question needs to be answered. I actually have an answer to my question, but wasn't sure if it was poor form to answer my own Q. But my friend's timing was pretty much perfect, and it motivated me enough to stop my current work and head over here to meta.economics. Is my question the wrong sort of question to ask? Does it belong in "Research Economics?" (Which I fear may be a long time in coming, if ever).
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/246/what-have-economists-written-about-the-recent-rise-in-income-inequality [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/143/price-adjustment-mechanism-for-market-clearing-in-hansens-1985-real-business

I thought I might chime in. For what it's worth, I have quite a lot of economics background - a graduate-level economics background, in particular. I'm hoping to make a career out of economic research at the frontier of knowledge and methodology, if I can help it. I'm just about to enter the "research" phase of my PhD, and would absolutely love to have a site where I can ask (and answer!) questions that are either research-related or "theory-backed policy or analysis"-related (heck empirical questions would be fine too). That'd be great.
Something that I (and friends of mine) been trying to figure out since the beta launch is "what level" this SE site is aiming for. Saying that a site should have questions in the range
"Econ 101" < ideal question <= graduate-level questions
is a pretty big range.
I mention this, of course, because I just witnessed what appears to be a pretty legitimate research-level-type [question attacked][1] for not including what the person was asking about -- references to literature about that topic.
I definitely consider that question to be a "literature review" type question, which I welcome and have no problem with. Here's why: part of being an expert in something means knowing that particular literature well. At the same time, you explicitly *don't* know the literature of other sub-fields well. That's fine, that's how being a researcher is designed. Expert in a narrow area and all. There is no shame in asking an expert in another sub-field what the literature in that field is. Thus the response to the question, that it should essentially *include* literature in its phrasing, strikes me as strange -- for a research-related site.
The response to the question makes a lot of sense, of course, if the site is supposed to be a place for people to debate current topics. "Back up your terminology!" and all. I was under the impression that that's not the point of this site, though.
I feel like that would actually make research economists *not* want to post any "literature review" type questions here. Am I going to be shot down for not linking to literature in my question about literature?
The other thing that prompted my question is that, as I was reading the above debate, another friend of mine -- doing economic research at the PhD level and following the site -- sent me a message: "looks like no ones answered [your question][2] yet. You think anyone will?"
Not that my question needs to be answered. I actually have an answer to my question, but wasn't sure if it was poor form to answer my own Q. But my friend's timing was pretty much perfect, and it motivated me enough to stop my current work and head over here to meta.economics. Is my question the wrong sort of question to ask? Does it belong in "Research Economics?" (Which I fear may be a long time in coming, if ever).
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/246/what-have-economists-written-about-the-recent-rise-in-income-inequality [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/143/price-adjustment-mechanism-for-market-clearing-in-hansens-1985-real-business

I'm pretty new to "meta" discussions, and still generally pretty new to the StackExchange network. So please forgive any stumbles.
I just posted my thoughts on the discussion about the "[income inequality][1]" question [over here][2].
I wasn't sure if it would be appropriate to repeat portions of it here. Please read my thoughts there. I think that was an entirely legitimate *research*-type question, for the reasons I state.
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/246/what-have-economists-written-about-the-recent-rise-in-income-inequality [2]: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/remember-exemplary-questions/53#53

I believe that it should state that any economics topic is on-topic including:
- Game theory - History of economics theory - History of the world economy - Study of incentives (this needs rewording) - Parts of consumer behavior that are strongly related to economics - Theories and models from economics applied to other areas of study - Data sources relevant for economists - Sources of any kind (including magazines) that are relevant or often used by hard-core economists
The reason why I want to include many border line topics, is that I believe that economists will not be offended by seeing these topics here. Also, I believe that the current pool of economists that are active on stack exchanges is limited, so economists that are interested in non-mainstream economics, should be welcomed. I believe that the initial success of stackoverflow was due to its scope being relatively broad. Later on it has been narrowed down slightly with off-shoots like superuser.com, serverfault.com and the Database Administrator stackexchange. The same could be done for this site, for example when/if the [game theory stack exchange][1] reaches enough committers.
What do you think?
EDIT: With regards to off-topic questions. I think we should write that users with a question regarding one of the many misconceptions about economics in the media, should rather ask their question on [the skeptics stack exchange][2]. The statement should, though, be reworded.
[1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/10447/game-theory [2]: http://skeptics.stackexchange.com/

I thought I might chime in. For what it's worth, I have quite a lot of economics background - a graduate-level economics background, in particular. I'm just about to enter the "research" phase of my PhD, and would absolutely love to have a site where I can ask (and answer!) questions that are either research-related or "theory-backed policy or analysis"-related (heck empirical questions would be fine too). Something that I (and friends of mine) been trying to figure out since the beta launch is "what level" this SE site is aiming for. Saying that a site should have questions in the range

is a pretty big range.
I mention this, of course, because I just witnessed what appears to be a pretty legitimate research-level-type [question attacked][1] for not including what the person was asking about -- references to literature about that topic.
I definitely consider that question to be a "literature review" type question, which I welcome and have no problem with. Here's why: part of being an expert in something means knowing that particular literature well. At the same time, you explicitly *don't* know the literature of other sub-fields well. That's fine, that's how being a researcher is designed. Expert in a narrow area and all. There is no shame in asking an expert in another sub-field what the literature in that field is. Thus the response to the question, that it should essentially *include* literature in its phrasing, strikes me as strange -- for a research-related site.
The response to the question makes a lot of sense, of course, if the site is supposed to be a place for people to debate current topics. "Back up your terminology!" and all. I was under the impression that that's not the point of this site, though.
I feel like that would actually make research economists *not* want to post any "literature review" type questions here. Am I going to be shot down for not linking to literature in my question about literature?
The other thing that prompted my question is that, as I was reading the above debate, another friend of mine -- doing economic research at the PhD level and following the site -- sent me a message: "looks like no ones answered [your question][2] yet. You think anyone will?"
Not that I'm demanding my question be answered. I actually have an answer to my question, but wasn't sure if it was poor form to answer my own Q. But my friend's timing was pretty much perfect, and it motivated me enough to stop my current work and head over here to meta.economics. Is my question the wrong sort of question to ask? Does it belong in "Research Economics?" (Which I fear may be a long time in coming, if ever).
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/246/what-have-economists-written-about-the-recent-rise-in-income-inequality [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/143/price-adjustment-mechanism-for-market-clearing-in-hansens-1985-real-business

I don't think so.
There still seems to be a healthy discussion on "what the site should be" and "how we should make it what we want it to be". We certainly don't need to solve those questions before opening, but I feel that they could be discussed and thought over a bit more.
Also -- I honestly don't think the site should be opened without LaTeX capability. When we open the site up, I and I'm sure other people will blast it to a lot of economist friends who could be potentially big contributors (ya know, like the 20% that do 80% of the work). I think for these people, having a positive impression and seeing LaTeX from day one will let people know the site can be used seriously and isn't just a forum for politics.

row.Comment: added 59 characters in body; edited title
row.Text: Are we ready to open the gates to public beta TODAY?

I disagree.
I believe that users should be strongly encouraged (with moderator enforcement) to use one of the common top-level [JEL classifications][1] as a tag, with possible additional sub-tags from sub-topics. Microeconomics and macro/monetary economics are two of the classifications in the JEL scheme. Based on the JEL scheme, I suggest the following "top-level tags."
- teaching - history-of-economics (note: not economic history) - methods - microeconomics - monetary-and-macroeconomics - international-economics - financial-economics - public-economics - health-and-welfare - labor - law - industrial-organization - business - development - economic-systems - natural-resource-economics - environmental-economics
Excluded JEL codes:
- N - Economic History (belongs on history.SE) - R - Urban, Rural, and Regional Economics (tag with specific region) - Y - Miscellaneous Categories (tag with specific category) - Z - Other Special Topics (tag with specific topic)
[1]: http://www.aeaweb.org/jel/jel_class_system.php

Let's use the [CrossValidated FAQ][1] as a template, as it seems to be the closest non-beta site to this one. Working off of that, I suggest:
Economics Stack Exchange is for academic and professional economists, economic policy experts, and anyone else doing economic research or interested in it as a discipline. If you have a question about
- History of Economic Thought - Microeconomics - Monetary and Macroeconomics - International Economics - Financial Economics - Public Economics - Health and Welfare Economics - Industrial Organization - Development Economics
then you're in the right place to ask your question.
The community aims to create a lasting record of great solutions to questions. Providing references to peer-reviewed literature or links to on-line resources is warmly welcomed. You can also incorporate the work of others under fair use doctrine, which particularly means that you must attribute any text, images, or other material that is not originally yours.
Homework questions are welcome. Please mark them with the homework tag. They get somewhat special treatment, because ultimately you benefit most by finding the solution yourself. The community will try to provide guidance, hints, and useful links.
There are certain subjects that will probably get better responses on our sister sites. If your question is about
- Statistics, ask on CrossValidated. - Misconceptions about economics in the media, ask on skeptics.stackexchange.com - Economic History, ask on history.stackexchange.com.
Please note, however, that cross-posting is not encouraged.
Please look around to see if your question has been asked before. It’s also OK to ask and answer your own question.
[1]: http://stats.stackexchange.com/faq

Do questions relating to history of the world economy (as opposed to history of economic thought) belong on this site, or would they be better served on [History Stack Exchange][1]?
[1]: http://history.stackexchange.com/
Is history of the world economy in scope?

So far we have [one data source question] which seems to have garnered some pretty good answers and could potentially serve as a valuable community resources. However, I think we need to lay out now our policy regarding future questions about data sources. I believe data sources questions should generally be consolidated into a single question on the site. Once activity has died down on the existing question, all answers should be further consolidated into one CW post (probably by a moderator) and all further questions should be closed as duplicates. Anyone have other suggestions?
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/179/89
How to handle questions about data?

A very small number of questions relating to web-based and video-game currencies have appeared ([here][1], [here][2]) and there has been some discussion ([here][3]) about them. I would like to know if people think that these questions, even if loosely based on Economics, detract from the site. They will certainly put serious economists off visiting us. Would people agree that we need a policy on this sort of question (with a view to discouraging them altogether for gamer forums to handle if they wish)?
I am aware that experimental web economies allow economists to pose new hypothetical questions, but they are so far removed from normal economic research that I feel we would need to see actual papers on them before they became worth discussing here.
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/40/is-greshams-law-relevant-for-modern-online-games-that-allow-the-use-of-real-mon [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/252/is-infinitely-divisible-fixed-quantity-currency-affectable-by-hoarding [3]: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/4/bitcoin-migration
Web-based currency questions

Most of the goldbug / bitcoin questions have been closed. There are still a couple out there that are problematic. So get in there, downvote the bad ones, vote to close them if they're off-topic, too basic (i.e. what an 18-year-old might ask a professor), or based on a faulty premise. And flag for deletion those that really need deleting.
I think we're on top of the bad stuff - as long as people keep voting to close the bad questions, we'll be able to keep things in order, between us.

First of all, there seems to be an implicit assumption that work needs to appear in "actual papers" in order to be deemed legitimate and worthy of discussion. Lots of terrific research in a variety of fields takes place outside of the model of peer-reviewed, hard-copy journals. If this is a result of a desire to keep so-called cranks away, the collective economic expertise of this site should be able to downvote and explain why their ideas lack merit (and if the experts can't explain this, then maybe the ideas do have merit and deserve inclusion).
I don't see why questions about web-based currency or video game currency would be off-topic. People buy real things in the real world with web-based currencies everyday, so those are real economies that happen to involve different assumptions from traditional currency. As for video game economies, I suspect the incentives are a bit different in that arena from traditional economies. That doesn't mean they warrant exclusion; just be clear about what assumptions are necessary and what are the implications of those assumptions. A lot can be learned by studying the effects of a change in assumptions (in the world of mathematics, this is what drove a lot of advances in geometry and abstract algebra in the last 200 years).
Although this is not directly related to economics, I feel the need to point out that epidemiologists have written (in [an actual paper!][1]) about the spread of infectious disease in World of Warcraft. Although there are many differences from a real-world epidemic, they felt there was nevertheless a lot to learn. Perhaps the expert economists here can take a page from their book.
[1]: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1473309907702128

Web-based currencies should be treated no differently from any other currency. If the question strays into personal finance matters, it's off-topic (should be on http://money.stackexchange.com). If it has nothing to do with Economics, it's off-topic. If it's soliciting opinion or only exists to be argumentative, and so on, it's not a good question.
I see no reason to believe that there cannot be serious academic questions about these currencies, and not all questions have to be "experimental". As well, it seems ridiculous to me that economists studying these emerging economic attributes of the internet would be prohibited from asking questions about them until a large body of work has been published. It would be akin to disallowing questions about new security issues on the IT Security site.

That question and its answers together is already pretty massive. I don't see how it's valuable at all. Most of the links have very little description attached to them, if any, and there's not much ranking. Making it a CW post would remove any ranking at all, and the post would grow ever more massive. Without CW it will grow to have more than one page of answers, which means that new answers get buried and never seen and the list stagnates.
Lists just don't work on Stack Exchange, and I think this question should be closed. A massive link dump is useful to no one; at some point it becomes like Google except bad for searching due to having much less descriptive material and so on.
What does work on SE is pointed, specific Q&A. Good resource questions look something like this:
>##How can I get accurate data on the number of small business owners in China?
>I've tried looking at <source> but the data is incomplete, and <other source> doesn't have anything on small business owners specifically. I need the data to be broken down by sex and age and no older than the 2008 numbers, so I can use it for <purpose>. How can I get this information?
Rather than digging through a massive list of general sources and hoping one has the information, the person who asks this sort of question can get a tailored answer that solves the specific problem they're facing.

Economists can perform **economic** analysis of an event better than a historian. In that sense, they're not history questions, they're economics questions. Questions that focus on the analysis of aspects other than the economic forces involved (etc.) should be off-topic since they are not economics questions, regardless of whether an event of great economic import is involved.
On-topic example (which may or may not suffer other problems):
>How did the New Deal affect interest rates?
Off-topic example:
>Did rates of mental illness rise during the Great Depression?

- Statistical Analysis has stats.stackexchange.com - Mathematics has math.stackexchange.com - User Experience has ux.stackexchange.com - Theoretical Computer Science has cstheory.stackexchange.com
I would like to propose that the main URL for this site be econ.stackexchange.com, possibly with economics.SE redirecting.
Can we get econ.stackexchange.com?

- Statistical Analysis has stats.stackexchange.com - Mathematics has math.stackexchange.com - User Experience has ux.stackexchange.com - Theoretical Computer Science has cstheory.stackexchange.com
I would like to propose that the main URL for this site be econ.stackexchange.com, with economics.SE redirecting. Note: it is currently the other way around, with econ.SE redirecting to economics.SE.

I think it is worth pointing out that currently only 4 users have at least 500 rep. Once the site moves to public beta, I believe it requires 500 rep to vote to close questions. As such, even if *every* person who *can* vote to close a question did so, it would not be enough without a moderator's help. Since it's especially important early on to close questions that don't belong, I think the site would need more high-rep users before progressing.

Ooh, I don't know, [Edward Castronova][1] at Indiana University has made his economics career out of the study of in-game economies, and a number of virtual worlds now employ economists to ensure the management of their currencies.
I think it's very useful to consider such questions no more nor less important.
[1]: http://mypage.iu.edu/~castro/home.html

Skeptics SE [requires reference][1]s in its answers and notable claims in its questions. I Think that this policy may make sense here though I would modify it slightly.
- Any claim of statistical trends, or actual economic conditions in a question should be required to be referenced.
- If the question is is the trend actually happening then the claim should be able (and required) to be referenced by some notable news source.
- Since these should be graduate level questions the Questioners should at least be able (and required) to show some relevant knowledge of the question and that they have at least attempted research by referencing documents of the topic where they are seeking clarification that does not fall into the previous categories. This would include questions of how does X fit with Y or What do economists say about Z.
- Since these are graduate level questions all answers should be able to be referenced.
These policies should help to mostly eliminate less useful and political questions about the economy. Or at least put them into an arena where they can be addressed with out the left vs right agenda pushing with out real data or research to back it up. The good questions I have seen seem to already be following this.
Does this not seem like a good policy?
[1]: http://meta.skeptics.stackexchange.com/questions/5/faq-must-all-answers-be-referenced

I'm not sure. @Matthew_Read pointed out that "link dumps" don't work. I don't have much experience with how links work on stack exchanges. However, I think it's valuable that people be able to ask about where to find data.
One proposal is that links to *individual* websites with single data sources should not be included. However, we should permit links to sites that already aggregate many data sources. For instance, the following link will probably be helpful to people.
http://rfe.org/toc.php?show=complete
Additionally, I think questions of the type, "Does anyone know where I can find data on weekly average prices charged by individual gas stations?" are fantastic. These are likely not in any well-known data set and I think it could be quite valuable for people to ask questions about "Where can I find *hard-to-find* type of Data X."

A couple of questions on the main board give us an opportunity to explore the question: when is a question about tools on-topic? The questions are: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/300/104 and http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/292/104
To me, neither of these are specifically about economics. In the former case, any STATA user would be interested in the answer, and may be in a position to ask it, and so Stats.SE looks like the right question for it.
In the latter case, I'm not sure where the best place for it is. It's a great question, and I'd love to see a great answer to it. But I'm not sure where it would live. There is an [academia proposal at area51][1], so maybe it could live there, if that ever went live.
Is it a sane and reasonable rule for the FAQ, that any tools question has to be about economics tools, and that the answerers are more likely to be economists than from any other field?
[1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/16617/academia?referrer=KHsGVyFAxlwjazD_NAENyw2
when is a question about tools on-topic?

This is a kind of tricky question. If the question were about **R**, it probably would be better suited for stats.SE. However, STATA is basically only used by economists or people in the social scientists. I don't know a single statistician who would use the program. Therefore, I think economists would be specially positioned to answer it.
I'd be curious though what people consider are good norms for not "cross-posting". If I'm interested in a question that seems relevant to economists, but might also be suited to another SE, should I look in all other possible SE's first before posting here?

Public beta *will* happen. Economics seems to be on the right track, but we don't quite have enough content here yet that new public beta users can use to figure out what they are expected to do (and not do) on the site. Keep going, keep the quality high, and we'll get there soon!

To my (limited) knowledge, this sort of question is discouraged on any SE. If I were to ask it on StackExchange (which has a Stata tag), I'm sure it would be closed as being non-answerable. A similar argument could be made re the question about managing references.
Often, it seems the questions I'd most like answers to are (rightly) closed because they don't fit the format of SE. Some of the best stackoverflow questions, for example, are even flagged with:
> This question exists because it has historical significance, but it is > not considered a good, on-topic question for this site, so please do > not use it as evidence that you can ask similar questions here.
See: [List of freely available programming books](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/194812/list-of-freely-available-programming-books)
So, the question is: should these types of questions ([Stata Question](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/300/what-is-a-good-text-editor-for-using-stata-for-mac), [Data Sources](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/179/what-are-the-most-useful-sources-of-economics-data) and [Research Tools](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/292/what-are-good-research-tools-for-managing-academic-papers)) be closed now (despite their obvious value to the community) to avoid having to include such a disclaimer in the future?
That said, some of the other SE sites seem to have a bit more of a discussion format (and are a bit more permissive) than what is shaping up here.

To my (limited) knowledge, this sort of question is discouraged on any SE. If I were to ask it on StackExchange ([which has a Stata tag](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/stata)), I'm sure it would be closed as being non-answerable. A similar argument could be made re the question about managing references.
Often, it seems the questions I'd most like answers to are (rightly) closed because they don't fit the format of SE. Some of the best stackoverflow questions, for example, are even flagged with:
> This question exists because it has historical significance, but it is > not considered a good, on-topic question for this site, so please do > not use it as evidence that you can ask similar questions here.
