That said, some of the other SE sites seem to have a bit more of a discussion format (and are a bit more permissive) than what is shaping up here.

I'd allow it.
In fact I would also allow more meta-questions like style of writing or publication in economics. They are not part of economics but they are part of the economist life and we'd all be interested in knowing the answer, I am sure.

Interesting question. We had the same question for ctheory.SE, and I'm not sure we took a real decision. Anyway we have now a tag "soft-question" for question around the field (papers, conferences, how to present work in progress, how to deal with some paper problems, what tool for what purpose, etc.). Afterwards, some of these questions are closed because they are of too low-level.

We should also avoid questions that the majority of working economists would deem as "unanswerable" or too likely to appear as quack questions like in the popular press.
For instance, questions of the type "How will the economy grow in Q4 of 2011", "Should I buy bonds or stocks", or similar questions should be discouraged. They are really better suited for a forum on finance or investing and definitely do not represent anything related to the study of economics.
This stackoverflow should **NOT** be a forum for people to have baseless arguments about generally unknowable or highly opinionated questions.

Soft questions, such as questions about economics tools or about "being an economist" or "the practice of economics" should generally be on-topic so long as the questions are specific to economics/economists and would not be potentially better suited to a sister SE site. Unless and until this site grows quite substantially, most statistics tools questions will be better off on stats.SE, and general academic questions (at least until [Academia SE][1] opens up) are better off on whichever sister site has the most academics.
[1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/16617/academia?referrer=S0HQbWuXT9gjazD_NAENyw2

MathJax is a pretty heavy dependency. If there is a demonstrated and significant need for it, we can turn it on. If it is just going to be a question here and there, it may not be worth the dependency.
--- Edit: MathJax has been enabled.

MathJax (LaTeX) has been enabled on the main site, and $$ not on meta$$ - and that's been standard for other SE sites with Mathjax too.
So what do we need in the FAQ, for MathJax and LaTeX?
What do we need in the FAQ for Mathjax, now that has been enabled?

As this Stack Exchange went into the public beta, what are the questions that are acceptable to be asked now, as opposed to the ones that were okay in the private beta?
Public beta - what questions can be asked now?

Hopefully, this will turn into a good FAQ question. Here's my stab at it - it's community wiki, so please go ahead and edit here, if you feel that this is a decent enough starting point.
--- Questions should: --
- be about economics - be based on one or more true premises - be likely to lead to a verifiably correct factual answer - be specific, practical, answerable questions based on actual problems that you face - be reasonably scoped - i.e. answerable in 1-5 paragraphs, and not require a whole (chapter in a) book. - be split into separate questions, when they are separate questions, even if they are closely related. Don't ask in a single question: "why are there inferior goods, and is X an inferior good, and why is Y not an inferior good?" That's three questions, and should be posted as three questions.
--- Questions should not: --
- be likely to lead to argument or prolonged discussion - be answerable by looking up in general reference - be about the operation of the site itself - those questions belong here on meta, not on the main site - duplicate previously-asked questions - be chatty or open-ended (if you want a discussion about something, take it over to the chat room) - too localised. If it is only relevant to a small geographic area, a specific moment in time, or an extraordinarily narrow situation that is not generally applicable to the worldwide audience of the internet, it's too localised. - be too vague to be answerable concisely
--- If it's a homework question, tag it with the "homework" tag. Answerers of such questions should give pointers to how to get to the right answer, rather than the right answer itself.

row.Comment: Just want to emphasize this because Too Localized shouldn't be used for closing questions about small countries' economies and so on

For those who simply want to include US dollars ($) instead of funky formatting, remember to escape the dollars:
\$
There's a discussion at [meta.stackoverflow][1] and an [alternative solution at the Electronic hardware SO][2] site.
[1]: http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/86860/mathjax-incorrectly-formatting-texts-containing-dollar-signs [2]: http://meta.electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/440/tex-delimiters-should-be-changed/613#613

Following on from http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/79/what-do-we-need-in-the-faq-for-mathjax-now-that-has-been-enabled/85#85 is it worth setting the inline-Mathjax delimiter on the main economics site to be \$ rather than $? We're probably going to have a lot more dollar signs than LaTeX, and those who are happy using LaTeX will probably be happy with a \$ delimiter; those who are just typing sentences with two separate dollar signs in them, are less likely to be comfortable with needing to escape them.
Thanks to @Turakawa for pointing out the [discussion at meta.stackoverflow][1] and the [\$ solution at the Electronics.SE site][2].
The [MathJax documentation recommends against just using $ as the inline Mathjax delimiter][3]:
> Note in particular that the $...$ in-line delimiters are not used by default. That is because dollar signs appear too often in non-mathematical settings, which could cause some text to be treated as mathematics unexpectedly. For example, with single-dollar delimiters, ”... the cost is $2.50 for the first one, and $2.00 for each additional one ...” would cause the phrase “2.50 for the first one, and” to be treated as mathematics since it falls between dollar signs
[1]: http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/86860/mathjax-incorrectly-formatting-texts-containing-dollar-signs [2]: http://meta.electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/440/tex-delimiters-should-be-changed/613#613 [3]: http://www.mathjax.org/docs/1.1/start.html#tex-and-latex-input
use \$ as the inline-Mathjax delimiter, rather than $

I agree, and the time to do this is now, before we have too many MathJax equations embedded in various questions and answers that will get broken by making this change. On this site probably more so than most, `\$` makes a lot of sense as the default in-line delimiter.

So while many economic researcher for obvious reasons deal with forecasting, I still want to ask if such questions are on-topic here? I don't mean forecasting exact development and data, but underlying data, nature and differences of forecasting models and determining factors.
There are currently two proposals on AREA51 having imho some serious overlap with economics.SE, but not attracting very much follower, I'm also unsure if they would generate ongoing questions. Imho economics.SE could absorb many questions intended for [futurology][1], while the more speculative ones like technological, environmental, demographic development are probably off-topic here. I think most [systems science][2] questions would actually fit here, as economics is mainly practical systems science, and systems science as a pure theory site is imho doomed to bust after 200 questions (Current questions all answerable by a textbook and many competing sites like math.SE, physics.SE, theophys.SE, climate change, economics.SE) There are enough programming, math and computer sites on SE for most non-real world complex systems. And real-world represent mainly biology, economics, climate modeling.
Please consider that questions on futurology are not intended to speculate about future events like the [singularity][3] proposal, so it wouldn't damage in any way the quality of this site. It's intended to discuss what factors, methods, models one should take into account for forecasting, not how to weight them, I know such Q&A would be subjectively and politically biased.
[1]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/34955/futurology-future-studies [2]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/29969/systems-science [3]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/26580/singularity
Are questions about forecasting methods and models welcome and on-topic here?

I noticed there are only 22 Beta badges awarded. How does this compare to other SO site launches in similar states of development, and is it a good, bad, or information-poor signal for the future success of the site?
How does the number of Beta badges compare to other SO sites - implications for success?

Well, considering I'm an economist and my entire functional role at my employer is to develop macro- and micro-economic modelling software and systems... yes, I definitely think that it is important. Partly because economics is becoming much more of a "hard science" than it used to be (requireing the ability to manipulate large amounts of quantitative data) and partly because many non-economists will be drawn into the field because of the need for quantitative models (much as happened to the biological sciences with the coming of the Human Genome Project).

Well, history.SE was launched at the same time as us and they have 40 beta badges. Yet their site seems a bit troubled and the SE team is still skeptical about whether it will ultimately work, while I think this site has gotten a pretty good (albeit small) expert audience with some decent questions and great answers, in my opinion.
Healthcare IT started a day later and has 24 beta badges.
Biblical Hermeneutics, on the other hand, started earlier and has just 17 beta badges awarded.
Overall, though, I think we should be paying most attention to our relative ranking on the [main home page][1]. Judging by that, I believe there is cause for concern, but I think it will simply take this site much longer than other SE sites to build an audience due to the relatively low overlap between professional economists and other popular SE topics (programming, hardware, gaming, even mathematics). Having said that, if you have any connections at universities, go out and evangelize! Encourage current PhD students to use this site to work through the multitude of smaller problems that come up in the process of writing a dissertation.
[1]: http://stackexchange.com/sites

Normative questions are, for want of [a definition][1]:
> In philosophy, normative statements affirm how things should or ought > to be, how to value them, which things are good or bad, which actions > are right or wrong. Normative is usually contrasted with positive > (i.e. descriptive, explanatory, or constative) claims when describing > types of theories, beliefs, or propositions. Positive statements are > factual statements that attempt to describe reality.
Experienced philosphers and economists will usually attempt to rephrase any question so that it is positive. A Q&A site dealing with economics will attract people less attuned to the dangers of normative questions and so we'll get stuff like:
- [What conventional (and wrong) wisdom about economics currently causes the most harm in international politics?][2] (which hasn't been closed as of this question)... - ... and many others which have been closed.
It takes time and energy to "police" these questions and re-edit them to ensure they aren't normative and can be answered in terms of fairly well-researched theory. That would - especially at the moment when there are few editors - lead to closing (as "discretion is the better part of valor").
I imagine that economics is going to have this to a greater degree than other Q&A sites but this is the way most non-economists think when they ask questions of economists.
How should we handle this in a way that is both appropriate and educational?
[1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normative#Philosophy [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/411/48
How should we respond to Normative questions?

Calling for a judgement (good or bad, better or worse) is begging for people to jump on their side of the question and get into a discussion. While there is nothing wrong with the discussion this site is a Q&A site not a discussion forum. You say the problem is not enough government intervention I say there is too much and it ends up in a debate where neither of us are right because there is no right or wrong... (Well I am right but the wrong side will never agree with that).

See [this Meta question][1] for the specific reason why they are not acceptable.

You make a great point that normative topics are OK if the question is specified in a positive way.
It seems like many questions may come from people who are seeking normative answers, but just don't know how to ask the question. For example, one might ask "is a flat tax good?" when they really want to know "what would be the various economic impacts of a flat tax relative to the current system in the U.S.?" In this case, a professional economist would likely give the same answer to both questions (he would just limit the scope of his answer to the former question).
In my experience, many people expect us to be able to answer the first question. **This brings us back to the question of whether or not this site is for "graduate and professional economists."** If so, then we can expect some precision in the questions. If not, then some help in formulating appropriate questions might be useful (e.g. do we need some sort of guide?). To my knowledge, the question of the site's audience is still unanswered, and it might be useful to settle that matter first.

**How do we resolve the question of whether the Economics StackExchange Still for Grad and Professional Q&A Only?**
I realize this topic has been discussed in other threads, but I don't think a clear consensus has been reached. The question was previously asked in [Graduate Level Questions](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/26/graduate-level-questions) but there was no final answer and the general belief seems to be that the answer might have changed when the site moved from private to public beta. To be clear, I am not asking the question again--I'm wondering how we know if/when the question has been answered, and what the answer is/was.
When I visit the site (without logging in), I still see: > Welcome to Q&A for economists and graduate-level economics students
But, in the comments to an answer on [Public beta - what questions can be asked now?](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/81/public-beta-what-questions-can-be-asked-now), @Chad asked
> So questions no longer need to be graduate level questions?
To which @EnergyNumbers responded:
> AIUI, that's right. But they shouldn't be answerable by general > reference either. And questions should show some research effort, and > be useful to others as well as the OP.
Further, there have been a number of undergraduate-level questions. These questions haven't gotten any comments about not being at the right "level" and all have net positive up-votes from the community. The revealed preference seems to be to accept these questions even though the site is still officially for grad/professional questions. A few examples:
- [What is a public good?](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/364/what-is-a-public-good) - [How to extract a set of values from a specific range of indexes](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/353/how-to-extract-a-set-of-values-from-a-specific-range-of-indexes) - [Choosing a profit-maximizing output given two markets](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/340/choosing-a-profit-maximizing-output-given-two-markets) - [Why would monopolist never produce at the inelastic part of the demand curve?](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/337/why-would-monopolist-never-produce-at-the-inelastic-part-of-the-demand-curve)
The acceptance of these questions stands in stark contrast to what was deemed acceptable during the private beta, and the official mandate of the site as laid out in the Area 51 proposal.
The audience of the site affects a variety of other factors. For example, I think the question to: [How should we respond to Normative questions?](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/92/how-should-we-respond-to-normative-questions) hinges largely on the audience of the site (see my answer to that question).
**I am not familiar with the procedures, but can someone please guide us towards resolving this question?** I think it is very important that an unambiguous standard be set, whatever that standard may be.
Is the Economics StackExchange Still for Grad and Professional Q&A Only?

This is a community site. Those of us who have (or still will) put in the time and effort to become trusted members and moderators will have undue influence (through edits and the ability to vote to close). In that respect, we have a more difficult role as we need to decide.
The questions you're asking (and that I'm taking a hit for asking, re normative) are essential to establishing what it is we would like the site to be. In answering that question we need to recognise that economics will always be a "social" subject. A person may not be a graduate or professional to notice something, describe it and ask - all without knowing what the technical terms are or even that it was resolved 200 years ago.
That said, we do need to maintain a particular standard.
My approach, rightly or wrongly, is based on 10 years of teaching non-economics undergraduate students economics (a bit like Freakonomics, really). I found that the best way to invite people with strongly-held normative or uninformed views towards a positive answer they could understand and accept was a polite and respectful assistance towards rephrasing their question.
I don't believe that flaming each other when these sorts of questions are asked will set the appropriate tone or create a sufficiently robust site that can survive for any length of time. It will become unpleasant for some and a very steep learning curve for others.
So, an answer (of sorts): those of us who take this seriously should consider rephrasing questions that we define as inappropriate and justifying quite clearly (and positively) why such a change was made.
Inappropriate gets back to your question. So, what's inappropriate:
- Any question which would result in the correct Wikipedia entry turning up in the first result of a Google search would be a good one to delete (or monitor, if they really do turn up frequently we may have to leave it there); - Any open-ended or unanswerable question which cannot be rephrased to be closed or positive (and that may not be immediately obvious from the question); - Specific questions about trading stocks or shares which would be better suited to Personal Finance and the Quant Stackexchanges;
Undergraduate, or lay, questions tend to fall into the easy or normative buckets. In which case there is already a single-point answer (Wikipedia) or they need to be rephrased. Perhaps, on rephrasing, we could create a small section header which says: **Normative versions of this Positive Question**.... and then details all the permutations which we observe.
A few ideas. Would be good to discuss answers now before market forces take it in a direction we cannot predict (but which is nevertheless "correct") ;p

Judging by the success of Freakonomics and the large number of me-too books which followed, many people who would never normally think about the academia of economics have been introduced to the subject.
Are questions like these acceptable?
- Does crime pay? - Do abortions lower crime? - Does my name influence my earning potential? - [Do safety features in cars increase the number of accidents?][1] (asked by @SinanÜnür)
I think that, carefully phrased, these are fantastic ways to introduce complex concepts and can also go some way to assisting in @JasonB's question about the academic level of questions on the site.
I would also suggest that, in honour of Steven Levitt, we clearly tag all such questions "freakonomics".
What does the community think?
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/392/48
Are Freakonomics-style questions welcome?

just my opinion:
I don't think we need to give the freakonomics guys any more free advertising than they've already had.
And I think that one thing that characterises Freakonomics is that it has often been normative questions and answers, dressed up as positive ones. Which is, to my mind, the worst of all worlds.
In several cases, pre-judged positions have meant that economic arguments have been coerced and co-opted into providing a quasi-objective camouflage for what would otherwise be a subjective position that bore only a flimsy relationship with reality.
So I'd say that the freakonomics brand, and all that goes with it, could be toxic for this site.
On the other hand, it clearly has a presence in public consciousness, so having some freakonomics bait for the search engines can't do any harm.
Perhaps the freakonomics tag should be reserved for non-normative questions about the specific issues in those books?

I think Freakonomics is certainly worthy of some credit--it went a long way towards showing the general public that economics is not just about money and that economic principles can be used to study many types of problems. Further, Levitt has pushed the boundaries a bit and he is most certainly a great (and brave) economist.
However, the application of economics to non-monetary problems did not begin with Freakonomics. Schelling, Becker, Nash and Hurwicz, to name just a few contemporary and well-known economists, were "applied" economists in the Levitt sense.
When the book came out, I thought "good, maybe this will help show people what economics is really about." I did **NOT** think "this book has invented a new way to think about and apply economics." It is unfortunate that Levitt was called a "rouge economist" and that the title of the book left the perception that Levitt's brand of applied economics was something completely outside the economic mainstream.
Tagging these problems "freakonomics" implies that we think these sorts of questions are outside the mainstream of economics--that they are freaky--while the truth is that it is not uncommon at all for economists to apply economic principles to problems that don't have dollar signs.
For these reasons, I respectfully request that we not tag such questions as "freakonomics" unless they are specifically about the book.

I think such questions are welcome. I'll add a few answers proposing various tags - please vote up any tags you think would be good, and vote down any tags you think would be inappropriate.
Proposed tag: **lateral-applications**

"unconventional applications"
But, I fear that tag is too many characters.

| does it use classical economic theory? | | yes | no | Are the risks | | | or rewards | | | financial? | | | ----------------|-----------------------|------------------------| yes | classical economics | behavioural economics | ----------------|-----------------------|------------------------| no | ? | behavioural psychology | ----------------|-----------------------|------------------------|
So how about **economic-behaviour**?

- Does crime pay? - Do abortions lower crime? - Does my name influence my earning potential? - [Do safety features in cars increase the number of accidents?][1] (asked by @SinanÜnür)

Update: and, blowing up the site with 10k views in it's first day, is this [perfect example about popcorn][2]. I think we need a tag for it reasonably soon...
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/392/48 [2]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/437/48

Nobel Prize Winner Gary Becker pioneered the application of economics to the analysis of human behavior. Seems to me that it is well within the scope of the site.
That said, we do not want the content dominated by "Freakanomics" type questions.

I guess we're at risk of receiving quite a few questions that give someone's pet theory, with no research behind it.
What should we do with them? Close, down-vote, answer, ignore?
pet theories with no research

I don't think the intent was to form an "ask the expert" site, but it looks like that's where it is headed. One recent questioner says he's done no research and justifies this with " I'm asking the experts a question." Another demands a defense of rationality itself.
Ignoring these questions is tempting, but risky. Ignoring the question leaves a vacuum that might be filled with junk answers. Several recent questions have received a number of very low-quality answers (e.g. answers starting with "I think" and/or answers devoid of any serious economic content). A site full of low quality answers will probably make us look worse than a site full of low-quality questions.
I'd say they should be closed unless some serious effort has gone into the "pet theory" -- after all, one can't simply propose a theory (or criticize core assumptions), then ask other people to do the work of proving or disproving it for him. That's not how science works, and that is, I assume, why we ask for questions that show research effort and precision.

I'll second Jason. I think a stupid (or, worse, rude and insulting) answer does far more damage than does an ill-informed question. Answering such a question simply and politely blocks trolls and closes that line of questioning down far more effectively than waiting for someone to just ask it again later on...

I think I was one of the pet theorists :-)
> I'm asking the experts a question.
I would have been content with my question being closed and would never have returned to this site, as it would have been abundantly clear that it is for
> economists [scientists?] and graduate-level economics students
**exclusively**, and if you don't show prior (academic??) research, the experts here are not interested in the question.
*However*, this is not like any other stackexchange site I visit works. (anything from SO to TEX to ENGLISH)
As far as I can tell, all stackexchange sites contain questions
* from (narrow) expert to (narrow) experts * from individual to crowd (often rightfully closed; some really good nonetheless) * from "laymen" to experts
I think it's the last category that would generate "pet theory" questions here on economics. *Personally*, as long as they cannot be answered by a trivial google search or by reference to a general textbook (or wikipedia article), I think they should be politely answered.
Possibly by telling (commenting?) the poster that his question makes no (scientific) sense, or that there can be no answer without severely constraining the question. After all, it is quite common for laymen to ask questions to which the only answer as professional can give is "it depends" :-)
<sub>Oh, and, Turukawa - thanks a bunch for [your answer][1] :-)</sub>
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/496/do-governments-through-their-reliance-on-debt-end-up-transferring-wealth-from/515#515

I realize that the answers posted on SE sites are not the property of the person answering, and that
- anyone may **edit** a post and - it is OK (even encouraged) to aggregate multiple answers into a summary answer
However, what is the policy on an answer that is nearly 100% cut-and-paste from a single answer with no attribution to the original author?
I'm referring to the answer by Kevin Riggle in [In a competitive market, why is movie theater popcorn expensive?](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/437/in-a-competitive-market-why-is-movie-theater-popcorn-expensive) @HighlyIrregular pointed out that it duplicates an answer by @user288.
KevinRiggle did remove some of the answer and added a sentence of his own. This kind of behavior is not accepted in academia, and would only be OK if the original content was quoted (e.g. using "User288 said:" then a blockqoute). **I went ahead and edited the answer accordingly.**
**Was this the correct action to take, or should I have flagged the answer (or left it alone)?**
Cut-and-Paste From Other Answers
I think you did exactly the right thing - and hit him with a downvote and a note to that effect - his point could have been a comment under user288's answer...

SE Economics is in danger of sinking without trace at the moment. What do people believe are the causes thus far, and what on earth can we do about it?
The metric that looks exceptionally low at the moment is "Questions per day". Having more questions is vital because there is virtuous circle of participation if there is a lot of discussion. Without new questions, site points are awarded too slowly, and these are an important incentive for people. **Can I suggest** that everyone takes the time to throw questions out there, even if you wouldn't normally consult others for that type of question. I see this as a temporary measure; otherwise the site desperately lacks participation.

Well, we also have a large body of unanswered questions. This goes back to notions about what sort of site you want this to be.
The unanswered questions tend to be quite esoteric bits of theory or homework-style questions; questions related to the academia of the subject.
The more popular questions are practical, often asked inexpertly by non-economists, and often voted for closure or censured (flamed to bits).
A popular site is likely to be less expert. An expert site is likely to be less popular. Of course, the two approaches don't have to be exclusive, but it does require a more tolerant approach ... always difficult on the anonymous intarwebs.
I'd suggest aggressive revision of normative or poorly phrased questions rather than deletion. I'd also move for deletion of all insults and flames. Keep comments on topic and the approach respectful.
We're going to need moderators to perform these tasks and I know there will be a few soon. In the mean time the most participative of us need to clean up as best we can within the rights we have.

I've noticed the lack of questions as well. I'm planning on trying to post one question per day that is not too esoteric and that I could potentially answer myself with more thought or talking to other people. For instance, I might ask the question when I don't know something and then if I figure it out a few days later come back and post an answer or contribute to other people's answers.
Is anyone else with me in trying to ask similar questions? This may help seed the webpage with more content/encourage better participation.

[tag:pop-economics] covers popular subjects on the subject of financial risks or rewards, using the tools of classical or behavioural economics.
[tag:lateral-applications] uses the tools of classical economics to deal with subjects where the risks and rewards are non-financial.

Here are a few more reasons why you did the right thing, and why the answer given by @Turukawa is a good practice for this site, in my opinion. I'm drawing from my observations as a user on other SE sites, particularly those with a lot of **prose** rather than code or formula-heavy content:
Standard **"protocol"** on SE sites is to mention the existence of a similar question or answer by URL in the question comments. That won't be misunderstood as *possible duplicate* if it is prefaced with a courteous, **"See this too, it might be helpful"**.
Also: Sometimes users don't feel energetic or have the time to write a decent answer. Yet they know that some or all of a few other question comments or answers would fully address a new question. That's okay! It takes time to write a decent answer, even if aggregating pieces of existing content.
I think it is much better to leave comments than enter a very poor quality answer. I often see one, occasionally see two SE URLs included in the same comment following a question. That is **so** preferable to a big concatenated copy-paste answer, even **with** attribution. There's a beta site I visit with some of the latter going on. It isn't appealing.
The other reason to leave the URLs in the comments is that if someone else comes along who has the time and energy, they can use that as a starting point for a good answer.

Throughout the beta, we need members from the site whose focus is to engage the community, both in community-building issues and site management. That's why we select a few members from each community to act as temporary, provisional Moderators. You can read about the program here: [**Moderators Pro Tempore**](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2010/07/moderator-pro-tempore/).
I am pleased to announce that these members have stepped up and generously volunteered their time to help us assure that each community’s issues are properly addressed:
[![Jason B][1]][a] [![Turukawa][2]][b] [![dchandler][3]][c]
We want to make this site a huge success, and these members are great examples of exactly the type of people we need to make this site succeed. Please welcome them for the hard work and time they contribute. ###Did I overlook anyone? Almost certainly. There are members who are actively involved and very deserving of recognition. My failure to account for everyone this early on is in *no way* a slight against them. Ideally, Moderators are elected by the community and that's why **you'll have your elections in several weeks.** Most of all, be respectful and understanding of the Moderators Pro Tem. Members of your community are volunteering their time and learning on the job. It’s a learning experience for everyone.

If I look at other stack exchanges such as http://quant.stackexchange.com/ or http://math.stackexchange.com/ I see a very high quality bar on the questions and answers.
Poorly framed questions are either edited or closed if they are incoherent or beyond the scope of the site. There are a number of questions and answers which are at the layman-level, or simply incoherent on its face, and will not attract a professional audience to this site.
Examples of such questions include:
- Do Banks Cause Inflation? What are other possible causes?
- Can There Be “Pent Up Demand” Even When People Are Broke?
- How do we calculate what the perfect amount of debt is?
There are also bad answers littered about as well.
As has been noted before, the initial questions and answers will set the tone for future visitors to the site.
I'd like to ask the moderators to apply higher standards to cleaning up these questions and answers so that we are meeting the standard set forth in the FAQ - "economists and graduate-level economics students."
Increasing the quality of questions and answers / Pruning the weeds

I agree that the quality needs to be kept high. However, I'm finding it a bit difficult for a few reasons.
1. There aren't many downvotes on questions. When the community has upvoted a question such that it has net upvotes, I'm hesitant to go against the community consensus and close it. All but one of the questions with < -1 net votes have been closed so far. For example, the three questions you listed all have net upvotes, and one had no downvotes at all. Are the quant and math communities more likely to downvote poor questions? 2. There aren't many suggested edits. Right now, there are no suggested edits in the queue. We need to get the entire community involved in editing questions. There seems to be a preference for commenting on the question instead of editing it directly (I'm guilty here too). 3. My understanding is that in SE poor *answers* are usually handled by downvoting them and that only **extremely** poor answers are deleted. I've deleted a couple of obvious ones. Please correct me if I'm wrong. 4. There is still some debate about the proper level of questions (e.g. whether the grad/professional hurdle still applies). As I understand it, the latest conclusion was to let the community set the standard dynamically with down/close votes. There is a [meta post on this topic](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/95/is-the-economics-stackexchange-still-for-grad-and-professional-qa-only), and **it would be great to have more opinions there** as I don't think the matter is quite settled yet.
Any opinion or advice would be appreciated!

There is a [new meta post asking for moderators to be more aggressive](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/125/increasing-the-quality-of-questions-and-answers-pruning-the-weeds) in getting rid of low-quality content. In my response, I've pointed out a few of the difficulties re deleting/closing, and would sincerely appreciate it if folks would add their opinion to that post. Ideally we can get some idea from the Econ SE community on how we want the site to be moderated--the moderation patterns/expectations established now will likely carry forward into the future.
A related issue is that we've not had much feedback on what level of questions are appropriate. It would be **extremely helpful** to have more feedback in the related meta question: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/95/is-the-economics-stackexchange-still-for-grad-and-professional-qa-only
I think I speak for @Turukawa and @dchandler when I say that we look forward to any feedback/criticism as we sort out just what the community wants.

I'm not sure the "revealed preference" of the community is a suitable beacon especially as the community is in its infancy. The measure of suitability should be the intended scope and audience of the site.
You will get plenty of upvotes on wrong answers, and upvotes on questions from casual passers-by. By definition expertise is something like a power-law -- concentrated at ever finer levels of gradation. In the beginning I think our moderators should be more assertive in pulling out the weeds rather than waiting for the voting system to self-police.
I don't see the same self-policing on this site as other sites, for whatever reason, so I do not think it is a good idea to rely solely on this lever.

This is a community site. Those of us who have (or still will) put in the time and effort to become trusted members and moderators will have undue influence (through edits and the ability to vote to close). In that respect, we have a more difficult role as we need to decide.
The questions you're asking (and that I'm taking a hit for asking, re normative) are essential to establishing what it is we would like the site to be. In answering that question we need to recognise that economics will always be a "social" subject. A person may not be a graduate or professional to notice something, describe it and ask - all without knowing what the technical terms are or even that it was resolved 200 years ago.
That said, we do need to maintain a particular standard.
My approach, rightly or wrongly, is based on 10 years of teaching non-economics undergraduate students economics (a bit like Freakonomics, really). I found that the best way to invite people with strongly-held normative or uninformed views towards a positive answer they could understand and accept was a polite and respectful assistance towards rephrasing their question.
I don't believe that flaming each other when these sorts of questions are asked will set the appropriate tone or create a sufficiently robust site that can survive for any length of time. It will become unpleasant for some and a very steep learning curve for others.
So, an answer (of sorts): those of us who take this seriously should consider rephrasing questions that we define as inappropriate and justifying quite clearly (and positively) why such a change was made.
Inappropriate gets back to your question. So, what's inappropriate:
- Any question which would result in the correct Wikipedia entry turning up in the first result of a Google search would be a good one to delete (or monitor, if they really do turn up frequently we may have to leave it there); - Any open-ended or unanswerable question which cannot be rephrased to be closed or positive (and that may not be immediately obvious from the question); - Specific questions about trading stocks or shares which would be better suited to Personal Finance and the Quant Stackexchanges;
Undergraduate, or lay, questions tend to fall into the easy or normative buckets. In which case there is already a single-point answer (Wikipedia) or they need to be rephrased. Perhaps, on rephrasing, we could create a small section header which says: **Normative versions of this Positive Question**.... and then details all the permutations which we observe.
A few ideas. Would be good to discuss answers now before market forces take it in a direction we cannot predict (but which is nevertheless "correct") ;p
UPDATED:
Responding to @QuantGuy, overcoming the "revealed preferences" is something we can now do (as moderators) but we do suffer from a "founder effect" - a small body of people some of whom may have particular biases - I think we should only close a question if thorough editing can't convert it into a meaningful question.

Following on from this meta question: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/q/61/104 I'd like to ask how many questions requesting sources of data do we consider to be acceptable?
We've had one general question already, that's been thoroughly answered: http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/179/104
how many data questions are reasonable

And, to kick things off, here's my answer to my own question - feel free to downvote if you disagree, upvote if you agree, and/or supply your own answer:
At least one data question is reasonable, and that's the general one linked in the question.
People seeking data questions should always try the leads provided there as a first resort, and only then, if they fail to find what they are looking for in those sources, should they pose a new data question.
I propose that data questions that haven't followed this procedure should be closed as duplicates of the general-data question http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/179/104

Thanks for bringing this back to the forefront.
An example of a well-intentioned, but ultimately unanswerable question problem is:
http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/670/birth-and-death-of-companies-and-related-issue
This question was just closed. It wasn't clearly about economics, showed no research effort and wasn't reasonably scoped. My comment to the author was:
> ...your question is appreciated. Unfortunately, as written, we can't > tell how you define "company" (F100 only? my uncle's hobby farm?), and > there is no geographic (global?), time or industry scope. In addition, > we ask that you very briefly describe what you've tried so far, why > that didn't work (it helps us avoid going down the same dead ends > you've surely already tried!), and how the problem relates to > economics (e.g. the problem that will be solved).
**I think the FAQ needs a special section about how to ask a data question** where we can point people who need guidance. I'll take an initial stab at it, but feel free to edit or comment:
**Questions About Data**
Before asking a question seeking a data source, we ask that first you try the sites listed in: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/179/what-are-the-most-useful-sources-of-economics-data
A question seeking a data source should specify:
- exactly what data are being sought (timeframe, subject, variables... please be very specific) - where you've already looked, and why those sources didn't work - what sorts of questions the data will be used to answer
Including these elements will make it more likely that you will get good answers to your question.

I believe we have some compelling content and are learning how to build the site. I think it is a good time to start promoting the site to the wider business and economics community.
Not sure what anyone's background here is but, if you happen to have contacts in the financial press (The Economist, Newsweek, Financial Times, etc) or any of the business news services (Bloomberg, CNN, Thomson-Reuters, etc.) now would be a good time to send them some info.
Not sure how the Q&A meta format works in terms of developing a press release, but here's some of my experience in writing PR:
- Help the journalist: they're on a deadline and looking for a story, give them some examples of things we - as a service - are most proud of (so choose particularly compelling Q&As based on your audience); - Give them specific objectives: the "call to arms" thing; what do we want from the reader of this release? - Be persistent: we need to keep doing this.
So, questions:
1. What are the current crop of Q&As we feel are the most representative and the best in terms of what we wish to stand for (and they don't, necessarily, have to be the ones that received the most votes or attention)? 2. What do we most want in terms of visits and response from our message?
How do we promote the site?

Jason_B has given this answer: http://economics.stackexchange.com/a/692/104 to a question that is at best odd - http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/688/104 . The answer is based on a single paper. It's quite a well-written answer, in that it describes the paper well. And I think that Jason_B has done a good job given a bad question, and given the apparent paucity of usable literature.
But I'm very uncomfortable with such a paper being given as the answer here - the paper is so flawed as to be worse than useless. I'd be strongly inclined to delete the question: I think that the site will be better without it.
I don't have enough rep to vote to delete. If I did, I would.
I think the combination of question and answer leaves a pretty nasty taste in the mouth.
An alternative would be to edit Jason_B's answer, so that all the problems of the paper were laid out at the top of the answer. But, done well enough, that would invalidate the rest of the answer, it seems to me.
A question that's so bad it risks the site's reputation

Are you asserting that the model gives no useful insight, or that it is offensive to your sensibilities? You might try flagging the answer or question for review (and I'll refrain from reviewing it) if you aren't satisfied by whatever result this thread produces.
I agree somewhat; this topic is not a comfortable one. I found the whole thing a bit offensive as well, but it didn't occur to me that the question or the referenced paper should be off limits for that reason. I'm largely indifferent about it, but I'll try to justify the question and answer because I think the implications of how this question is handled will be important for how we handle other controversial questions in the future. **If it were just about this question, I'd simply withdraw my answer out of respect for your opinion** (leaving the decision on the final disposition of the question itself to someone else.
I edited @JimThio's original question to make it a little tighter and more professional. I don't think the question itself is offensive as edited. I also think the question is odd, but as (re)written it is clearly an economics question (and in scope). But let me know if you disagree.
**(In?)famous paper**: The answer was obvious as I recalled having the referenced paper (Edlund and Korn) in my files (he was originally asking if there was any research on this topic). The paper is a curiosity indeed, and is worth reading if only for the attention it received when originally published. Further, while it seems quite a bit off, it did appear in the JPE [(2002 v10 n1)](http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/324390), which by itself makes the paper relevant (but not necessarily right of course).
**Paper taken seriously**: E&K's paper has been taken seriously in serious journals, for example by Arunachalam and Shah (AER 2008) who call it a "seminal paper." Their main objection is to E&K's simplifying assumption that a prostitute cannot later marry, a claim for which they find no empirical evidence. They assert an "alternative hypothesis" to explain sex workers' relatively high wages: that the profession exposes its workers to a higher risk (they focus on STDs).
**Criteria for Judging the Worth of a Model**: Instead of just summarizing the results. I went through the paper in some detail, trying to highlight some of the assumptions they made. I think I made it pretty clear that some of the assumptions are unrealistic (and even offensive). But if we are to exclude literature with unrealistic assumptions then that will very much limit the set of economics papers we can use on this site. The usual process is to think about a model in the context of its assumptions--that is, just what insights we can take from a model are limited by the assumptions. The usual criterion is not whether the model is right, but whether any useful insights can be gained from it.

I'm trying to settle on the text for our FAQ. We previously discussed the text for the FAQ in http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/81/public-beta-what-questions-can-be-asked-now. However, as far as I can tell, we can only edit the "What kind of questions can I ask here?" section, not "What kind of questions should I not ask here?". So, I've reworked it a bit (see below). I'm putting this in a separate question to make sure everyone notices it and has a chance to comment. I'm a bit worried that there are too many rules--feel free to consolidate/shorten.
Please feel free to edit (I've made this a wiki) and upvote if you feel that the text below is appropriate. Without objection, I'll update the FAQ on Monday the 26th.
=====Begin Suggested Text======
The economics stack exchange is intended for students and professionals in economics.
If your question is:
- about economics, - based on one or more true premises (which are backed up by reference to formal literature if the premises aren't common knowledge), - likely to lead to a verifiably correct factual answer rather that opinion or discussion, - based on actual problems that you face, - reasonably scoped - i.e. answerable in 1-5 paragraphs, and not require a whole (chapter in a) book, - specific (e.g. there is only one question per post, and it is clear what is being asked) and - written from an unbiased, neutral point of view and in a professional tone.
Then it is likely appropriate for our forum.
We ask that you do some research before asking by:
1. Trying to solve the problem yourself and/or doing some research (as appropriate). Please let us know what you've done so far to start answering the question. 2. Searching our archives to make sure your question hasn't been asked before.
Some types of questions require special treatment:
- **Homework** questions are welcome if they are marked with the **homework** tag. - If your question is about **finding data**, please look at our [useful sources of economic data](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/179/what-are-the-most-useful-sources-of-economics-data). When asking your question, please indicate why the sources listed there did not meet your needs.
Please be sure that your question is specifically about economics. Some questions may be better suited to our sister sites:
- [StackOverflow](http://StackOverflow.com)- for help programming an analysis - [Quantitative Finance](http://quant.stackexchange.com/) - for questions about finance - [Personal Finance](http://money.stackexchange.com/) - for questions about personal investment - [Statistics](http://stats.stackexchange.com/) - for non-economic statistical analysis (questions about economic statistics, including econometrics, are welcome here)
Text for the FAQ

I'm trying to settle on the text for our FAQ. We previously discussed the text for the FAQ in http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/81/public-beta-what-questions-can-be-asked-now. However, as far as I can tell, we can only edit the "What kind of questions can I ask here?" section, not "What kind of questions should I not ask here?". So, I've reworked it a bit (see below). I'm putting this in a separate question to make sure everyone notices it and has a chance to comment.
Please feel free to edit (I've made this a wiki) and upvote if you feel that the text below is appropriate. Without objection, I'll update the FAQ on Monday the 26th.
I'm a bit worried that there are too many rules--feel free to consolidate/shorten.
Note that this FAQ would have a bit of a different tone from the usual SE FAQs. They tend to list subjects that are appropriate. Economics covers so many potential topics that it would be difficult to create an exhaustive list of what is appropriate.
=====Begin Suggested Text======
The economics stack exchange is intended for students and professionals in economics.
If your question is:
- about economics, - based on one or more true premises (which are backed up by reference to formal literature if the premises aren't common knowledge), - likely to lead to a verifiably correct factual answer rather that opinion or discussion, - based on actual problems that you face, - reasonably scoped - i.e. answerable in 1-5 paragraphs, and not require a whole (chapter in a) book, - specific (e.g. there is only one question per post, and it is clear what is being asked) and - written from an unbiased, neutral point of view and in a professional tone.
Then it is likely appropriate for our forum.
We ask that you do some research before asking by:
1. Trying to solve the problem yourself and/or doing some research (as appropriate). Please let us know what you've done so far to start answering the question. 2. Searching our archives to make sure your question hasn't been asked before.
Some types of questions require special treatment:
- **Homework** questions are welcome if they are marked with the **homework** tag. - If your question is about **finding data**, please look at our [useful sources of economic data](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/179/what-are-the-most-useful-sources-of-economics-data). When asking your question, please indicate why the sources listed there did not meet your needs.
Please be sure that your question is specifically about economics. Some questions may be better suited to our sister sites:
- [StackOverflow](http://StackOverflow.com)- for help programming an analysis - [Quantitative Finance](http://quant.stackexchange.com/) - for questions about finance - [Personal Finance](http://money.stackexchange.com/) - for questions about personal investment - [Statistics](http://stats.stackexchange.com/) - for non-economic statistical analysis (questions about economic statistics, including econometrics, are welcome here)

There is a new question by the same questioner, [Does marriage terms tend to kick out more desirable mates/males out of mating market for some beautiful women?][1]. That "question" is even worse. It looks manly like an anti-feminist rant. It actually manages to satisfy every single criteria in the FAQ for [questions one should not ask][2].
I think we should apply very high standards to sensitive issues such as ethnicity, gender, religion etc. A non-scholarly question such as this one a sensitive issue seems to be unacceptable to me.

In [The decline and revival of Keynesianism][1] we have a "marignally" normative question. Certainly, the asker claims that Keynes lost dominance and has now returned. Practicing economists may debate this but, if you were simply reading the news, then this is a valid assumption to make.
The question is, how do we deal with this (especially with a request to close that question)? I feel that it is valid and should be left to be answered as best (and delicately) as we can within the minefield any answer would present.
Further, where a question is not strictly normative I still feel we should leave it. If it ends up with a tremendous negative score and no answers after a period of several months then a case can be made for close/delete but I would leave it till then.
Comments/suggestions?
[1]: http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/922/the-decline-and-revival-of-keynesianism#question
Keynes and marginally normative questions
Everyone ok if I create: economic-cycle and fiscal-policy? Any further requests for new tags?

As I understand the SO system, post flags are not intended to replace close votes, down votes, editing and commenting. The system is intended to be primarily moderated by the community, with moderators only acting to handle corner cases, and to quickly take care of really egregious problems.
In some relatively rare cases, it is obvious that a post is outside the FAQ (or just plain abusive)--the moderator has an easy job in those cases, and can speed up the community process by closing/deleting.
This post is slightly out of bounds given the FAQ, for example it makes some claims without giving evidence, and it doesn't show any research effort. My gut reaction was that the post wasn't so bad as to be harmful to the reputation of the site, and it might even be repairable with savvy editing.
As I see it, the job of moderators is changing as the site gets more members with 500+ rep. In the beginning, the moderator close vote was more critical as there weren't enough users with the close-voting privilege to close a bad post. Now, there are enough users with the close privilege, but there aren't many. In borderline cases I'd now guess that moderators should wait for at least a few close votes.
As the site evolves to have, say, 20-30 users with 500+ rep, I'd guess that the moderators will only be justified in acting on obvious cases, leaving the community process to handle the others.
But, I'd be happy to hear another opinion as I may have things entirely wrong.

I think I remember a discussion on Meta.SO about giving diamond-moderators two types of Close vote: the binding moderator one, and a standard-user (need 5 to close) one. I think in these marginal cases, having that option would be useful: perhaps our mods might consider deploying a standard-user need-5-to-close vote on questions where a binding moderator close vote seems too heavy-handed.
In lieu of that the alternative might be for diamond moderators to comment if they were minded to close it: and if the number of close votes plus the number of such comments reached 5, then a diamond mod could exercise the binding close vote.
Hardly a streamlined or satisfactory process, but maybe it could be useful for the occasional borderline case. Or take individual questions over to general (rather than moderator) chat, for an open discussion as to its close-worthiness.

The problem you're running into is not a perl problem, but something else. Economics has an additional javascript library for LaTeX formatting (called MathJAX), which also uses dollar-signs. I suspect this is where you're running into the problem.

I found a rendering bug in sites that are run in the ServerFault like [economics.stackexchange.com](http://economics.stackexchange.com). I was trying to build up some REPs there with a [question about unequal wealth distribution](http://economics.stackexchange.com/q/1028/734) -- I knew the answer, so I thought that it was a good place to start.
I asked the question, and everything was going really well.
Then I tried to answer the question. Here I encountered a problem. If you prefix the dollar sign `$` by a number some really obscure and broken formatting kicks in. However, you can disable the annoying formatting by escaping the dollar sign with `\`; the problem is you *can not* use the method if the dollar-sign prefixes a number prefixing a period. like `\$4.`
In PERL you'd write this like `/$\d+\.$/`. On any line matching that the formatting breaks. I can provide a patch if needed.
Markdown is broken!

Works for me on Linux/Chrome:
![picture of bug][1]
[1]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/dwOi0.png

Markdown is not broken.
This site uses LaTeX. In your answer, you'd escaped some of the dollar signs, but not all of them. Your markdown was broken: the site's markdown is fine.
By the way, please read the FAQ: > You should only ask practical, answerable questions based on actual problems that you face.
Posting a question to rep-farm is not asking a question based on actual problems that you face. Please delete the question immediately.

The site description seen by new visitors is currently:
> This is a collaboratively edited question and answer site for economists and graduate-level economics students
**Let's change it. Suggestions please!**
My reasoning: I think it may be unnecessarily putting people off, and it does not accurately reflects the range of questions we've had. We've accepted and answered quite a lot of questions that are from a more basic level than graduate level.
We did discuss this during the private beta - http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/q/26/104 - but that was the **private** beta, and there were very good reasons for keeping it to a high level **during the private beta**. But we're not in private beta any more, we're trying to get out of beta and into the mainstream of StackExchange sites.
We discussed it again in Nov 2011 - http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/q/95/104 - and the feeling seemed to be that we'd be more open to more basic questions, as long as they were, or could be edited into, meaningful non-normative questions - see [Turukawa's excellent answer][1] to that question
So, what description should greet new visitors, to encourage them to post good questions?
[1]: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/a/96/104
Are we still a site for economists and graduate-level economics students?
Please suggest text to replace the current description of us as a site "for economists and graduate-level economics students"

As mentioned in [the recent blog post](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2012/04/when-a-site-grows-quiet/), I must reluctantly announce that we'll be shutting this site down on Friday, May 4th, 2012. While a fine topic, progress here has been slow for some time now, and it simply does not appear that economics has a strong enough following on our network to support the site long-term:
> But when a site struggles to maintain any semblance of steady progress — when it's struggling to garner an audience, a healthy core of experts, and a steady stream of questions — it becomes increasingly unlikely that the site will find a core audience to sustain it.
So rather than stringing you along with hope of eventual graduation, I'd like to thank you all for the time and effort you've put in here, and encorage you to continue persuing your interest in the subject - either elsewhere on Stack Exchange, or elsewhere on The Internet.
I hasten to add, this is probably not the end of economics as a topic of interest on Stack Exchange, whether as a part of other sites, or as its own site reborn in the future on [Area 51](http://area51.stackexchange.com/).
In the meantime, the questions and answers posted here will be made available for [download and re-use](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/09/creative-commons-data-dump-sep-11/) by anyone who wants them.
Finally, if you see a question here that would make a good addition to a different site, please flag it for moderator attention in the next few days and suggest that it be migrated.
Economics is closing

As mentioned in [the recent blog post](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2012/04/when-a-site-grows-quiet/), I must reluctantly announce that we'll be shutting this site down on Friday, May 4th, 2012. While a fine topic, progress here has been slow for some time now, and it simply does not appear that economics has a strong enough following on our network to support the site long-term:
> But when a site struggles to maintain any semblance of steady progress — when it's struggling to garner an audience, a healthy core of experts, and a steady stream of questions — it becomes increasingly unlikely that the site will find a core audience to sustain it.
So rather than stringing you along with hope of eventual graduation, I'd like to thank you all for the time and effort you've put in here, and encourage you to continue pursuing your interest in the subject - either elsewhere on Stack Exchange, or elsewhere on The Internet.
I hasten to add, this is probably not the end of economics as a topic of interest on Stack Exchange, whether as a part of other sites, or as its own site reborn in the future on [Area 51](http://area51.stackexchange.com/).
In the meantime, the questions and answers posted here will be made available for [download and re-use](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/09/creative-commons-data-dump-sep-11/) by anyone who wants them.
Finally, if you see a question here that would make a good addition to a different site, please flag it for moderator attention in the next few days and suggest that it be migrated.
Fair enough. Hopefully this will make room for a Research Economics site (as listed on area51).

I respect your decision to close the site--I'm sure that the decision wasn't made lightly. That said, I disagree about the long-run viability of this site. Since the decision has already been made, I'll not attempt to make that case here.
In the future, you might benefit from consulting with the members of a site when you start to notice that things are not progressing as well as you'd like. It is possible that this or other closures could be avoided by taking some proactive steps, and a consultation with the site's users might just reveal what is working and what isn't. In contrast, we received this eviction notice with no warning, and with no attempt or opportunity to take any corrective action. That is certainly your prerogative as the site's owner, although it is also disappointing given the SE emphasis on "community" (vs a top-down management system).
In any case, I thank the StackExchange folks for their efforts and willingness to have a go at creating an economics SE, and wish everyone who has participated in creating this great community all the best.

Since the site is shutting down on May 4th, 2012, what are some good alternative to it? By good, i mean active community and open to questions from students.
Thank you in advance for all your recommendations.
Alternative to Economics Stack Exchange?

One alternative would be to start an open-source Q&A clone, and seed it with data from Economics.SE
There are [several available off the shelf][1], and the one I've deployed myself is [OSQA][2] which is written in django/python.
AFAIK, as yet, the datadump for econ.SE hasn't been made available. Apparently, at some point, it should be available from the [Area 51 econ.SE page][3]
The difficulty would be in capturing the traffic from SE: I'd wager that the StackExchange team would not be keen on any redirect to a competing Economics site
[1]: http://meta.stackoverflow.com/a/37953/164022 [2]: http://osqa.net [3]: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics

This definitely deserves to be shut down. All of the questions are either "can you do my remedial homework for me?" or "can you speculate wildly on this major global economic issue?" or "How do I explain [X] given that [something that is wrong and/or self-contradictory?"
Until people learn how to ask good economic questions, the site would never be more than a bunch of schmucks trying to figure out if they care enough to tell the new guy why it's impossible to answer his question.

Now that [this site will soon be closed down](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/159/economics-is-closing) along with [a bunch of other quiescent SE beta sites](http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2012/04/when-a-site-grows-quiet/), it might be a good idea to migrate out any questions that would be a good fit for other Stack Exchange sites. [This is already being done](http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/130342/salvage-questions-on-closed-sites-via-migration) for some of the other sites being closed. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any single SE site that could reasonably "swallow us whole", but our scope does overlap with several other sites that could be encouraged to cherry pick selected questions from here before this site is closed down completely.
Here are some established SE sites that might be interested in some of our questions:
* [Mathematics.SE](http://math.stackexchange.com): mathematical topics, including game theory * [Stats.SE / Cross Validated](http://stats.stackexchange.com): statistics, econometrics ([tag](http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/econometrics)) * [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com): computer programming
Several beta SE sites might also want some of our questions, particularly these two:
* [Quantitative Finance beta](http://quant.stackexchange.com): professional and academic questions on quantitative finance * [Personal Finance and Money beta](http://money.stackexchange.com): basic and personal finance
Some of the questions here could perhaps also fit on these sites:
* [History beta](http://history.stackexchange.com): economic history ([tag](http://history.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/economic-history)) * [Cognitive Sciences beta](http://cogsci.stackexchange.com): behavioral economics, psychology * [Computational Science beta](http://scicomp.stackexchange.com): computational methods
If you want to help with saving what's worth saving here, the first steps are to:
* start a thread on the target site's meta (and link it back to here), and/or * just start flagging high quality questions for migration if you believe them to be on topic elsewhere.
Note that _we only have about a week to do this!_ The Stack Exchange folks have said that they may be willing to [extend the deadline to allow for active migration to finish](http://meta.stackoverflow.com/a/130347), but that does require that we at least get the process started well before that.
(Personal disclaimer: I'm not an economist, and I never even knew there was an Economics.SE site before I found out that it was about to be closed. I just felt, as someone tangentially interested in the topic, that I should at least make an effort to keep some of the content here alive and on the web, rather than just collecting digital dust in a compressed archive somewhere.)

Thanks Ilmari,
To be clear, if someone wants to see a question saved, the easiest way is to flag it for moderator attention then state which site the question should be migrated to. The alternative is to choose "it doesn't belong here" -> off topic -> belongs on another site."
If no questions are flagged, then it's possible that none will be migrated.

* [Philosophy beta](http://philosophy.stackexchange.com/) ([meta thread](http://meta.philosophy.stackexchange.com/a/372)) * [Academia beta](http://academia.stackexchange.com/) ([meta thread](http://meta.academia.stackexchange.com/questions/109/economics-se-is-closing-some-questions-could-be-migrated) / [local post](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/173/questions-relevant-to-academia-se))
If you want to help with saving what's worth saving here, the first steps are to:
* start a thread on the target site's meta (and link it back to here), and/or * just start flagging high quality questions for migration if you believe them to be on topic elsewhere.
Note that _we only have about a week to do this!_ The Stack Exchange folks have said that they may be willing to [extend the deadline to allow for active migration to finish](http://meta.stackoverflow.com/a/130347), but that does require that we at least get the process started well before that.
(Personal disclaimer: I'm not an economist, and I never even knew there was an Economics.SE site before I found out that it was about to be closed. I just felt, as someone tangentially interested in the topic, that I should at least make an effort to keep some of the content here alive and on the web, rather than just collecting digital dust in a compressed archive somewhere.)
